Knowledge Point: Polar questions in Ulwa are identical in form to their \isi{declarative} counterparts. They are recognizable, however, through \isi{pragmatic} factors and through \isi{phonology} (\isi{intonation}). First, context often makes it apparent that a \isi{question}, rather than a statement, is being formed by the speaker. Second, polar questions are identifiable through a rising \isi{intonation}. The questions presented in \REF{ex:syntax:1} through \REF{ex:syntax:4}, if given the right context and said without a rising \isi{intonation}, could all also function as statements.
Content 1: \gsrc Itom mï awal tembi wap. | \gll itom mï awal tembi wap | \gls father 3SG.SUBJ yesterday bad be.PST | \glt (a) ‘Was father sick yesterday?’
Content 2: \gsrc Alum mï ikali ya ndïsina. | \gll alum mï i-kali ya ndï=si-na | \gls child 3SG.SUBJ hand-send coconut 3PL=push-IRR | \glt (a) ‘Can the child catch the coconuts?’

Knowledge Point: Perhaps especially in \isi{leading question}s, Ulwa can employ the \isi{interjection}s a ‘eh?’ or e ‘eh?’ as a \isi{tag word} at the end of the \isi{interrogative} sentence. These forms are common also in \ili{Tok Pisin}, which possibly played a role in their use in Ulwa. These \isi{tag word}s serve as an additional means of indicating that a sentence is a \isi{question}, as seen in \REF{ex:syntax:5}, \REF{ex:syntax:6}, and \REF{ex:syntax:7}.
Content 1: \gsrc Alo un apa map \textbf{a}? | \gll ala=o un apa ma=p \textbf{a} | \gls PL.DIST{=voc} 2PL house 3SG.OBJ=be INTERJ | \glt ‘Hey, you all -- are you home?’
Content 2: \gsrc Ngun andin ngun mundu ngunas \textbf{a}? | \gll ngun andin ngun mundu ngun=asa \textbf{a} | \gls 2DU DU.DIST 2DU hunger 2DU=hit INTERJ | \glt `You two, you two over there -- you’re hungry, yeah?’
Content 3: \gsrc U ango anmbï mbi \textbf{e}? | \gll u ango an-mbï mbï-i \textbf{e} | \gls 2SG NEG out-here out-go.PFV INTERJ | \glt `You didn’t come out, eh?’

Knowledge Point: There are not many examples of these tag \isi{interjection}s in my corpus. Although examples \REF{ex:syntax:5} through \REF{ex:syntax:7} might suggest a contrast in \isi{polarity} between the \isi{interjection}s a ‘eh?’ and e ‘eh?’, I do not suspect that such a contrast exists.
Content 1: \gsrc Alo un apa map \textbf{a}? | \gll ala=o un apa ma=p \textbf{a} | \gls PL.DIST{=voc} 2PL house 3SG.OBJ=be INTERJ | \glt ‘Hey, you all -- are you home?’
Content 2: \gsrc U ango anmbï mbi \textbf{e}? | \gll u ango an-mbï mbï-i \textbf{e} | \gls 2SG NEG out-here out-go.PFV INTERJ | \glt `You didn’t come out, eh?’

Knowledge Point: Polar questions may be answered with full sentences, with \isi{paralinguistic gesture}s, with general-purpose \is{exclamation} exclamatory \isi{interjection}s (such as m ‘mhm’), or with the designated \isi{response} \isi{interjection}s ‘yes’ or ‘no’. The word iyo ‘yes’ (with the alternate form iya ‘yeah’) is used for the \isi{affirmative}, and the word ase ‘no’ (with the alternate form asa ‘nah’) is used for the \isi{negative}. To disagree with a \isi{negative} proposition in a \isi{question}, a speaker may answer ‘yes’. Thus, for example, the answer to \REF{ex:syntax:7} is provided in \REF{ex:syntax:8}.
Content 1: \gsrc U ango anmbï mbi \textbf{e}? | \gll u ango an-mbï mbï-i \textbf{e} | \gls 2SG NEG out-here out-go.PFV INTERJ | \glt `You didn’t come out, eh?’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Iya} nï awal mbi lïmndï tawatïp ndale. | \gll \textbf{iya} nï awal mbï-i lïmndï tawatïp ndï=ala-e | \gls yes 1SG yesterday here-go.PFV eye child 3PL=see-DEP | \glt `Yes, I came out yesterday and watched the children.’

Knowledge Point: Content questions in Ulwa rely on several different wh- words, which are presented in \REF{ex:syntax:9}. For more on \isi{interrogative pronoun}s, see \sectref{sec:6.5}. There are no \isi{interrogative verb}s in Ulwa.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The \isi{interrogative pronoun} angos ‘what?’ is discussed in \sectref{sec:6.5}. Examples \REF{ex:syntax:10} and \REF{ex:syntax:11} demonstrate its use in texts.
Content 1: \gsrc A nïnji nungol ala \textbf{angos} landa? | \gll a nï-nji nungol ala \textbf{angos} la-nda | \gls ah 1SG-POSS child PL.DIST what eat-IRR | \glt `Ah, what will my children eat?’
Content 2: \gsrc U \textbf{angos} natan? | \gll u \textbf{angos} na-ta-n | \gls 2SG what DETR-say-IPFV | \glt `What are you saying?’

Knowledge Point: As mentioned in \sectref{sec:8.3.2}, the \isi{question word}s angos ‘what?’ and ango ‘which?’ likely derive from the \isi{negation} marker ango ‘\textsc{neg}’. This may suggest that content questions in general may derive from \isi{polar question}s (e.g., a \isi{question} like ‘what will my children eat?’ in \REF{ex:syntax:10} would have its origin in something like ‘will my children not eat?’).\footnote{Similarly, \isi{interrogative pronoun}s like kwa ‘who? [\textsc{sg]}’ and kuma ‘who? [\textsc{nsg]}’ are \isi{colexified} with \isi{indefinite pronoun}s. Thus, content questions such as the one in \REF{ex:syntax:13} may thus derive from \isi{polar question}s (i.e., ‘who is carrying it?’ < ‘is someone carrying it?’).}
Content 1: \gsrc A nïnji nungol ala \textbf{angos} landa? | \gll a nï-nji nungol ala \textbf{angos} la-nda | \gls ah 1SG-POSS child PL.DIST what eat-IRR | \glt `Ah, what will my children eat?’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Ko} mat inde? | \gll \textbf{ko} ma=tï inda-e | \gls one 3SG.OBJ=take walk-IPFV | \glt `Who is carrying it around?’

Knowledge Point: Sentences \REF{ex:syntax:12} and \REF{ex:syntax:13} provide examples of kwa ‘who? [\textsc{sg}]’ (further discussed in \sectref{sec:6.5}). This form is often shortened to [ko]. Whereas the form kwa ‘who? [\textsc{sg}]’ refers to exactly one referent, the form kuma ‘who? [\textsc{nsg]}’ refers to two or more referents.\footnote{Thus the number distinction made in the words meaning ‘who?’ (or ‘whose?’) is a binary distinction of \isi{singular} versus \isi{non-singular}, as opposed to the three-way contrast of \isi{singular}, \isi{dual}, and \isi{plural} that runs throughout many other paradigms in the language.}
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Kwa} tïki man tïnangana? | \gll \textbf{kwa} tïki ma=n tïnanga-na | \gls one again 3SG.OBJ=OBL arise-IRR | \glt `Who will get it [= the school] up again?’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Ko} mat inde? | \gll \textbf{ko} ma=tï inda-e | \gls one 3SG.OBJ=take walk-IPFV | \glt `Who is carrying it around?’

Knowledge Point: As mentioned in \sectref{sec:11.1}, there is no so-called wh-movement in Ulwa; all content questions are asked \isi{in-situ} -- that is, with the questioned element occurring in the same place where it would occur in an equivalent \isi{declarative} sentence. Thus, kwa {\textasciitilde} kuma ‘who?’ or angos ‘what?’ occur in the subject position when the questioned element is the subject of a clause, and they occur in the object position when the questioned element is an object. Likewise, kwanji {\textasciitilde} kumanji ‘whose?’ occurs immediately before the \isi{possessed} NP, just as would any \is{possessive pronoun} possessive pronominal marker. Thus, for example, in \REF{ex:syntax:14}, the ‘who(m)?’ element occurs in the position typically held by objects.
Content 1: \gsrc U man \textbf{ko} lïp sina? | \gll u ma=n \textbf{ko} lï-p si-na | \gls 2SG 3SG.OBJ=OBL one put-PFV push-IRR | \glt `Whom will you blame?’

Knowledge Point: In questions of countable quantity, the \isi{question word} anjika ‘how many?’ appears after the \isi{noun phrase} whose quantity is the topic of questioning. This could be either a subject or an object (or even an \isi{oblique} \isi{phrase}). The word anjika ‘how many?’ is thus syntactically identical to any modifying \isi{adjective} and -- in particular -- to \isi{numeral}s, which immediately follow the enumerated NP. Its use is exemplified in \REF{ex:syntax:15} and \REF{ex:syntax:16}.
Content 1: \gsrc Wambana \textbf{anjika} inim mo man? | \gll wambana \textbf{anjika} inim ma=u ma-n | \gls fish how.many water 3SG.OBJ=from go-IPFV | \glt `How many fish are swimming?’
Content 2: \gsrc U wambana \textbf{anjika} tïn? | \gll U wambana \textbf{anjika} tï-n | \gls 2SG fish how.many take-PFV | \glt `How many fish did you catch?’

Knowledge Point: It should be noted that questions of non-countable quantity -- that is, questions about \isi{mass noun}s (i.e., ‘how much?’) -- are not asked with anjika ‘how many?’. Rather, such \isi{interrogative}s can only be formed as ‘yes/no’ questions, in which an inquiry is made whether the amount in question is ‘big’ or ‘little’, as seen in examples \REF{ex:syntax:17}, \REF{ex:syntax:18}, and \REF{ex:syntax:19}.
Content 1: \gsrc U inim \textbf{ambi} amap? | \gll u inim \textbf{ambi} ama-p | \gls 2SG water big eat-PFV | \glt `How much water did you drink?’
Content 2: \gsrc U inim \textbf{ilum} amap? | \gll u inim \textbf{ilum} ama-p | \gls 2SG water little eat-PFV | \glt `How much water did you drink?’
Content 3: \gsrc Nungol mï inim \textbf{ambi} ame? | \gll nungol mï inim \textbf{ambi} ama-e | \gls child 3SG.SUBJ water big eat-IPFV | \glt `How much water does the child drink?’

Knowledge Point: Other \isi{question word}s, such as anjikaka ‘how?’ and angwena ‘why?’ cannot serve as either subject or object of a \isi{predicate}. Accordingly, they may be considered \isi{oblique}s. Their position in a clause is thus akin to the positioning of \isi{adverb}s -- that is, following the subject (when expressed) and preceding the entire verb \isi{phrase}, including the object of the verb if the verb is \isi{transitive}, as seen with the form anjikaka ‘how?’ in \REF{ex:syntax:20} and \REF{ex:syntax:21}.
Content 1: \gsrc U \textbf{anjikaka} apa maytap? | \gll u \textbf{anjikaka} apa ma=ita-p | \gls 2SG how house 3SG.OBJ=build-PFV | \glt `How did you build the house?’
Content 2: \gsrc Alimban mï \textbf{anjikaka} lamndu masap? | \gll Alimban mï \textbf{anjikaka} lamndu ma=asa-p | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ how pig 3SG.OBJ=hit-PFV | \glt `How did Alimban kill the pig?’

Knowledge Point: This is the same position as other \isi{oblique}s, such as \isi{postpositional phrase}s, as illustrated by \REF{ex:syntax:22}, or \isi{oblique}-marked NPs, as illustrated by \REF{ex:syntax:23} (\sectref{sec:11.4}).
Content 1: \gsrc Alimban mï \textbf{tïn mol} lamndu masap. | \gll Alimban mï \textbf{tïn} \textbf{ma=ul} lamndu ma=asa-p | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ dog 3SG=with pig 3SG.OBJ=hit-PFV | \glt `Alimban killed the pig with the dog.’
Content 2: \gsrc Alimban mï \textbf{mananï} lamndu masap. | \gll Alimban mï \textbf{mana=nï} lamndu ma=asa-p | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ spear=OBL pig 3SG.OBJ=hit-PFV | \glt `Alimban killed the pig with the spear.’

Knowledge Point: Although glossed in \REF{ex:syntax:20} and \REF{ex:syntax:21} as a monomorphemic word, anjikaka ‘how?’ is actually analyzable as anjika-ka ‘how.many-let’.\footnote{It may even be analyzable further (cf. the possible etymology of anjika ‘how many?’ presented in \REF{ex:otherwc:148} in
Content 1: \gsrc U \textbf{anjikaka} apa maytap? | \gll u \textbf{anjikaka} apa ma=ita-p | \gls 2SG how house 3SG.OBJ=build-PFV | \glt `How did you build the house?’
Content 2: \gsrc Alimban mï \textbf{anjikaka} lamndu masap? | \gll Alimban mï \textbf{anjikaka} lamndu ma=asa-p | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ how pig 3SG.OBJ=hit-PFV | \glt `How did Alimban kill the pig?’
Content 3: Not found

Knowledge Point: \sectref{sec:8.3.2}).} In other words, the final element is taken to be the \isi{perfective}/\isi{imperfective} form of the \isi{irregular verb} ka- ‘let, leave, allow’ (\sectref{sec:9.2.3}). Though perhaps having undergone a process of \isi{grammaticalization} and now often analyzed simply as ‘how?’, the word’s \isi{verbal morphology} is apparent in sentences such as \REF{ex:syntax:24} through \REF{ex:syntax:29}, which reflect the \isi{irrealis} form laka(na) ‘let [\textsc{irr}]’ of the verb.
Content 1: \gsrc Itom mï \textbf{anjikalaka} apa maytana? | \gll itom mï anjika-\textbf{la-ka} apa ma=ita-na | \gls father 3SG.SUBJ how.many-IRR-let house 3SG.OBJ=build-IRR | \glt `How will father build the house?’
Content 2: \gsrc U ndït indata ndïn \textbf{anjikalakana}? | \gll u ndï=tï inda-ta ndï=n anjika-\textbf{la-ka-na} | \gls 2SG 3PL=take walk-COND 3PL=OBL how.many-IRR-let-IRR | \glt `What will you do with them if you carry them around?’

Knowledge Point: Note that these \isi{irrealis}-marked forms of this \isi{question word} often convey a sense other than strictly ‘how?’, as examples \REF{ex:syntax:26} through \REF{ex:syntax:29}, which are translated as ‘what will [someone] do?’. The \isi{irrealis} examples notwithstanding, elsewhere throughout this grammar the form anjikaka ‘how?’ is glossed simply as ‘how?’, without being analyzed as being polymorphemic.
Content 1: \gsrc Nga kwa \textbf{anjikalakana} mane? | \gll nga kwa anjika-\textbf{la-ka-na} ma-n-e | \gls SG.PROX one how.many-IRR-let-IRR go-IPFV-DEP | \glt `What is this one going to do?’
Content 2: \gsrc U ndït indata ndïn \textbf{anjikalakana}? | \gll u ndï=tï inda-ta ndï=n anjika-\textbf{la-ka-na} | \gls 2SG 3PL=take walk-COND 3PL=OBL how.many-IRR-let-IRR | \glt `What will you do with them if you carry them around?’

Knowledge Point: Idiomatically, anjika ‘how many?’ can also be used to ask a \isi{question} somewhat akin to \ili{English} ‘what happened to [someone]?’, or ‘what’s up with [someone]?’, as seen in \REF{ex:syntax:30}.
Content 1: \gsrc Mï nan mat a u \textbf{anjika}? | \gll mï na=n ma=ta a u \textbf{anjika} | \gls 3SG.SUBJ talk=OBL 3SG.OBJ=say ay 2SG how.many | \glt ‘He said to her: “Ay, what happened to you?”’

Knowledge Point: As mentioned in the discussion of \isi{interrogative pronoun}s (\sectref{sec:6.5}), questions of ‘which?’ are formed with ango ‘which?’, \isi{homophonous} with the \isi{negative} marker and likely derived from it. The two differ, however, in terms of syntactic position: whereas the \isi{negative} marker typically follows the grammatical subject, the \isi{question word} ‘which?’ precedes the NP it modifies (whether subject, object, or \isi{oblique}). Sentences \REF{ex:syntax:31}, \REF{ex:syntax:32}, and \REF{ex:syntax:33} provide additional examples of ango ‘which?’ as it is used in questions.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Ango} wa makape wombïn? | \gll \textbf{ango} wa maka=p-e wombïn | \gls which village thus=COP-DEP work | \glt `Which village has work like this?’
Content 2: \gsrc U \textbf{ango} tïlwa u mbi? | \gll u \textbf{ango} tïlwa u mbï-i | \gls 2SG which road from here-go.PFV | \glt `Along which road have you come here?’
Content 3: \gsrc Mbïpïta \textbf{ango} ini mawat pïta? | \gll mbï-p-ta \textbf{ango} ini ma=wat p-ta | \gls here-be{-cond} which ground 3SG.OBJ=atop be{-cond} | \glt `If [they] stay, which ground will they live on?’

Knowledge Point: The \isi{interrogative word} angos ‘what?’ may be used in a similar fashion, modifying an NP (by preceding it) to ask ‘what kind of?’ or ‘what sort of?’, as in \REF{ex:syntax:34} and \REF{ex:syntax:35}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ayndin nï \textbf{angos} na ukïna? | \gll Ayndin nï \textbf{angos} na u=kï-na | \gls [name] 1SG what talk 2SG=say-IRR | \glt `Ayndin, what should I say to you?’
Content 2: \gsrc Una wandam mawap \textbf{angos} wombïn ninda? | \gll unan wandam ma=wap \textbf{angos} wombïn=n ni-nda | \gls 1PL.INCL jungle 3SG.OBJ=be.PST what work=OBL act-IRR | \glt `[When] we are in the jungle, what [sort of] work will [we] do?’

Knowledge Point: Questions of \isi{time} are asked by combining ango ‘which?’ with tem ‘time’, the latter word \isi{borrow}ed from \ili{Tok Pisin} taim ‘time, when’. Thus, quite transparently, \isi{temporal} questions in Ulwa are rooted in a \isi{phrase} meaning ‘which time?’. This \isi{phrase} occurs in the canonical position for \isi{temporal adverb}s (e.g., umbe ‘tomorrow’, amun ‘now’, etc.). In other words, ango tem ‘when?’ occurs immediately following the subject NP, as illustrated by \REF{ex:syntax:36}, whose answer is given in \REF{ex:syntax:37}.
Content 1: \gsrc Kapos mï \textbf{ango} \textbf{tem} lamndu masap? | \gll Kapos mï \textbf{ango} \textbf{tem} lamndu ma=asa-p | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ which time pig 3SG.OBJ=hit-PFV | \glt `When did Kapos kill the pig?’
Content 2: \gsrc Kapos mï \textbf{awal} lamndu masap. | \gll Kapos mï \textbf{awal} lamndu ma=asa-p | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ yesterday pig 3SG.OBJ=hit-PFV | \glt `Kapos killed the pig yesterday.’

Knowledge Point: Sentence \REF{ex:syntax:38} and \REF{ex:syntax:39} provide additional examples of ango tem ‘when?’.
Content 1: \gsrc Itom mï \textbf{ango} \textbf{tem} utam mamap? | \gll itom mï \textbf{ango} \textbf{tem} utam ma=ama-p | \gls father 3SG.SUBJ which time yam 3SG.OBJ=eat-PFV | \glt `When did father eat the yam?’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Ango tem} man ninda? | \gll \textbf{ango} \textbf{tem} ma=n ni-nda | \gls which time 3SG.OBJ=OBL act-IRR | \glt `When will [we] do it?’

Knowledge Point: Alternatively, the \isi{phrase} ango tem ‘which time?’ (i.e., ‘when?’) can take the \isi{oblique marker} =n ‘\textsc{obl}’, thus forming a phase meaning ‘with which time?’ (i.e., ‘at which time?’), as in \REF{ex:syntax:40} and \REF{ex:syntax:41}.
Content 1: \gsrc Kapos mï \textbf{ango} \textbf{temnï} lamndu masap? | \gll Kapos mï \textbf{ango} \textbf{tem=nï} lamndu ma=asa-p | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ which time=OBL pig 3SG.OBJ=hit-PFV | \glt `When did Kapos kill the pig?’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Ango temnï} natana? | \gll \textbf{ango} \textbf{tem=nï} na-ta-na | \gls which time=OBL DETR-say-IRR | \glt `When will the meeting start?’

Knowledge Point: Spatial questions are also formed with the \isi{question word} ango ‘which?’. Unlike \isi{temporal} questions, however, ango ‘which?’ usually occurs without overtly modifying any noun, such as, for example, a word meaning ‘place’. That is, when taken alone, ango ‘which?’ is understood to mean ‘which \isi{location}?’. Again, the spatial \isi{question word} (or, possibly, abbreviated phrase) occurs in the same position as spatial modifiers in \isi{indicative} clauses, as illustrated by the pair of examples \REF{ex:syntax:42} and \REF{ex:syntax:43}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ankam mï \textbf{ango} i? | \gll ankam mï \textbf{ango} i | \gls person 3SG.SUBJ which go.PFV | \glt `Where did the person go?’
Content 2: \gsrc Ankam mï \textbf{ngaya} i. | \gll ankam mï \textbf{ngaya} i | \gls person 3SG.SUBJ far go.PFV | \glt `The person went far away.’

Knowledge Point: \isi{Motion} verbs in Ulwa can be \isi{transitive}, taking a \isi{goal} argument as their \isi{direct object}. Thus, in questions of ‘where to?’ or ‘whither?’, the \isi{question word} ango ‘which?’ occurs in object position, as illustrated by the pair of examples \REF{ex:syntax:44} and \REF{ex:syntax:45}.
Content 1: \gsrc Tangin mï \textbf{ango} i? | \gll Tangin mï \textbf{ango} i | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ which go.PFV | \glt `Where did Tangin go?’
Content 2: \gsrc Tangin mï \textbf{wa} may. | \gll Tangin mï \textbf{wa} ma=i | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ village 3SG.OBJ==go.PFV | \glt `Tangin went to the village.’

Knowledge Point: As the object of the verb i ‘go.\textsc{pfv}’, the noun wa ‘village’ can be indexed with the \isi{object marker} ma= ‘\textsc{3sg.obj}’ in \REF{ex:syntax:45}. Critically, however, the \isi{object marker} is not permitted in questions such as in \REF{ex:syntax:44}. Its inclusion would render an interpretation of [ango] as ‘\textsc{neg}’ rather than as ‘which?’, as illustrated by \REF{ex:syntax:46}.
Content 1: \gsrc Tangin mï \textbf{wa} may. | \gll Tangin mï \textbf{wa} ma=i | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ village 3SG.OBJ==go.PFV | \glt `Tangin went to the village.’
Content 2: \gsrc Tangin mï \textbf{ango} i? | \gll Tangin mï \textbf{ango} i | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ which go.PFV | \glt `Where did Tangin go?’
Content 3: \gsrc Tangin mï \textbf{ango} may. | \gll Tangin mï \textbf{ango} ma=i | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ NEG 3SG.OBJ=go.PFV | \glt (a) ‘Tangin did not go [there].’

Knowledge Point: The \isi{source} of \isi{motion} (i.e., \isi{origin}), on the other hand, can be indicated as the object of the \isi{postposition} u ‘from’. Thus, in questions of ‘where from?’ or ‘whence?’, the \isi{question word} ango ‘which?’ occurs as the object of the \isi{postposition} u ‘from’, as seen in the pair of sentences \REF{ex:syntax:47} and \REF{ex:syntax:48}.
Content 1: \gsrc U \textbf{ango} \textbf{u} mbi? | \gll u \textbf{ango} \textbf{u} mbï-i | \gls 2SG which from here-go.PFV | \glt `Where did you come from?’
Content 2: \gsrc Nï \textbf{wandam} \textbf{u} mbi. | \gll nï \textbf{wandam} \textbf{u} mbï-i | \gls 1SG jungle from here-go.PFV | \glt `I came from the jungle.’

Knowledge Point: Indications that ango ‘where?’ is \isi{elliptical} for ‘which place?’ come from sentences such as \REF{ex:syntax:49}, which contains the entire \isi{phrase} ango luwa ‘which place?’. This lengthier method of asking ‘where?’, however, seems to be relatively uncommon.
Content 1: \gsrc Popo ndï un \textbf{ango luwa} pe. | \gll popo ndï u=n \textbf{ango} \textbf{luwa} p-e | \gls papaya 3PL 2SG=OBL which place be{-ipfv} | \glt `Where are your papayas?’

Knowledge Point: It may be noted that something of the \isi{negative} sense of [ango] is perhaps preserved in example \REF{ex:syntax:49}, since this is a \isi{rhetorical question} meant to imply ‘you have no papayas’. Sentence \REF{ex:syntax:50} is another example in which the full \isi{phrase} ango luwa ‘which place?’ occurs.
Content 1: \gsrc Popo ndï un \textbf{ango luwa} pe. | \gll popo ndï u=n \textbf{ango} \textbf{luwa} p-e | \gls papaya 3PL 2SG=OBL which place be{-ipfv} | \glt `Where are your papayas?’
Content 2: \gsrc Ngun \textbf{ango luwa} wap? | \gll ngun \textbf{ango} \textbf{luwa} wap | \gls 2DU which place be.PST | \glt `Where were you?’

Knowledge Point: As a modifying element, the ango ‘which?’ component of the abbreviated \isi{phrase} ‘which place?’ can receive the \isi{copular enclitic} or be followed by a \isi{locative verb}, thereby serving as the \isi{predicate} of its own clause, as in examples \REF{ex:syntax:51}, \REF{ex:syntax:52}, and \REF{ex:syntax:53}.
Content 1: \gsrc Unan \textbf{angop}? | \gll unan ango=\textbf{p} | \gls 1PL.INCL which=COP | \glt `Where are we?’
Content 2: \gsrc U \textbf{ango wap}? | \gll u ango \textbf{wap} | \gls 2SG which be.PST | \glt `Where were you?’
Content 3: \gsrc Yanapi mï \textbf{angopïna}? | \gll Yanapi mï ango=\textbf{p-na} | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ which=COP-IRR | \glt `Where will Yanapi be?’

Knowledge Point: Such clauses with \isi{verbalized} ‘where?’ constructions can combine with other clauses, as in the \isi{question} in \REF{ex:syntax:54}.
Content 1: \gsrc Itom mï \textbf{angope} lamndu masap? | \gll itom mï ango=\textbf{p-e} lamndu ma=asa-p | \gls father 3SG.SUBJ which=COP-DEP pig 3SG.OBJ=hit-PFV | \glt `Where did father kill the pig?’\footnote{Note that the \isi{verbalized} ango ‘which?’

Knowledge Point: In a similar sentence, but with \isi{irrealis} \isi{modal}ity, the verb in each of the two clauses would be marked for \isi{irrealis} or \isi{conditional} \isi{mood} \REF{ex:syntax:55}.
Content 1: \gsrc Itom mï \textbf{angopïta} lamndu mawalinda? | \gll itom mï ango=\textbf{p-ta} lamndu ma=wali-nda | \gls father 3SG.SUBJ which=COP-COND pig 3SG.OBJ=hit-IRR | \glt `Where will father kill the pig?’

Knowledge Point: Finally, ‘why’ questions are formed with the \isi{question word} angwena ‘why?’. Although this is pronounced as a single word, it, too, likely derives from a \isi{phrase} containing ango ‘which?’. The second element probably derives from na ‘talk, \isi{speech}, story, message, thought, reason, language’, here having the sense of ‘reason’ (i.e., ‘[for] what reason?’).\footnote{It is unclear why the form is pronounced as [angwena] as opposed to the expected \textsuperscript{†}[angona], but the pronunciation may have changed due to a folk etymological association with ina ‘liver’, the seat of reasoning and emotion in the Ulwa conception of the human body. This form also appears in words such as inakawana- ‘think’ (see \sectref{sec:9.2.1} for a proposed etymology). \citegen[3260]{Laycock1971a} field notes seem to indicate that the \ili{Yaul} \isi{dialect} form is angola ‘why?’ (Appendix \ref{sec:app.g}), thereby supporting the etymology of *ango ‘which?’ + *la ‘talk, reason’.} The \isi{question}s in \REF{ex:syntax:56} through \REF{ex:syntax:59} all contain angwena ‘why?’.
Content 1: \gsrc U \textbf{angwena} mbi? | \gll u \textbf{angwena} mbï-i | \gls 2SG why here-go.PFV | \glt `Why did you come here?’
Content 2: \gsrc Un \textbf{angwena} mawat pe ne? | \gll un \textbf{angwena} ma=wat p-e ni-e | \gls 2PL why 3SG.OBJ=atop be{-dep} act-IPFV | \glt `Why are you doing [things] during it [= this period of mourning]?’

Knowledge Point: Ulwa \isi{interrogative} constructions have the productive ability to \isi{question} multiple things simultaneously. Like \ili{English} constructions such as who gave what to whom?, Ulwa constructions may inquire into multiple unknowns. An example of an Ulwa multiple-\isi{question} construction is given in \REF{ex:syntax:60}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Ango} luwa \textbf{angos} nji ndïlanda? | \gll \textbf{ango} luwa \textbf{angos} nji ndï=la-nda | \gls which place what thing 3PL=eat-IRR | \glt `Where will [we] find something to eat?’

Knowledge Point: Whereas \ili{English} constructions like who gave what to whom? are mostly limited to situations in which it is assumed by the asker that each \isi{question} component has a known referent, Ulwa multiple-\isi{question} constructions are more flexible. Thus, for example, the two \isi{question}s ‘where will we find food?’ and ‘what food will we find?’ may be combined into something like ‘where will we find what food?’, a sentence that would stretch the capacities of \ili{English} multiple-\isi{question} constructions. Examples \REF{ex:syntax:61},\footnote{Admittedly, this sample sentence is not a prototypical multiple-\isi{question} construction, since one of the two questioned elements is perhaps more properly considered an \isi{indefinite pronoun} (\sectref{sec:6.4}) as opposed to a wh- word. An alternative analysis of these multiple \isi{question}s would be that these are sets of conjoined phrases with no overt \isi{conjunction} (e.g., ‘at what place and what thing will we eat?’, ‘from which place and what thing can we two get for them?’, etc.).} \REF{ex:syntax:62}, and \REF{ex:syntax:63} illustrate more multiple-\isi{question} constructions of this type.
Content 1: \gsrc U \textbf{ango} luwa \textbf{angos} matïn? | \gll u \textbf{ango} luwa \textbf{angos} ma=tï-na | \gls 2SG which place what 3SG.OBJ=take-IRR | \glt `Where will you get something?’
Content 2: \gsrc Ngan ndandï \textbf{ango} luwa u \textbf{angos} tïna? | \gll ngan ndï=andï \textbf{ango} luwa u \textbf{angos} tï-na | \gls 1DU.EXCL 3PL=for which place from what take-IRR | \glt `From which place can we two get what for them?’
Content 3: \gsrc E ngusuwa ko \textbf{angwena} \textbf{angos} mundu wananda nat? | \gll e ngusuwa ko \textbf{angwena} \textbf{angos} mundu wana-nda na-ta | \gls ay poor just why what food cook-IRR DETR-say | \glt `Ay, why did that poor thing say that he would cook whatever kind of food?’

Knowledge Point: Multiple \isi{question}s can also be expressed in what are clearly multiple clauses. In \REF{ex:syntax:64}, the \isi{conditional} form -ta ‘\textsc{cond}’ marks the end of the first clause – that is, the \isi{protasis}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ndï \textbf{ango} luwa wandam luta \textbf{angos} mundu malan? | \gll ndï \textbf{ango} luwa wandam lo-ta \textbf{angos} mundu ma=la-n[da] | \gls 3PL which place jungle go-COND what food 3SG.OBJ=eat-IRR | \glt `Where will they go and what will they eat?’

Knowledge Point: Questions often serve rhetorical purposes – that is, a speaker may not be actually requesting information, but rather may be making an argument (usually anticipating a \isi{negative response} to the \isi{rhetorical question}). Example \REF{ex:syntax:65} illustrates how these may be made in Ulwa.
Content 1: \gsrc Ndï nji ndïwatlunda? | \gll ndï nji ndï=wat-lo-nda | \gls 3PL thing 3PL=atop-cut-IRR | \glt `Will they clear the things?’

Knowledge Point: Rhetorical questions can be either \isi{polar question}s or \isi{content question}s. In polar rhetorical questions, the anticipated \isi{response} is ‘no’; in content rhetorical questions, the anticipated \isi{response} is ‘nothing’, ‘nowhere’, ‘nobody’, and so on. Example \REF{ex:syntax:66} contains first a \isi{polar question}, and then a \isi{content question}.
Content 1: \gsrc U ko wandam nji ndï \textbf{ango luwa} pe? U ko lïmndï ndala? | \gll u ko wandam nji ndï \textbf{ango} \textbf{luwa} p-e u ko lïmndï ndï=ala | \gls 2SG just jungle thing 3PL which place be{-dep} 2SG just eye 3PL=see | \glt `Where are your jungle properties? Do you see them?’

Knowledge Point: The first \isi{question} is literally ‘Your jungle things have which place?’ The anticipated \isi{response} to it is: ‘No place’. The anticipated \isi{response} to the second \isi{question} is: ‘No’. Example \REF{ex:syntax:66} also illustrates the use of the \isi{modal adverb} ko ‘just’, which may be used for emphasis in rhetorical questions.
Content 1: \gsrc U ko wandam nji ndï \textbf{ango luwa} pe? U ko lïmndï ndala? | \gll u ko wandam nji ndï \textbf{ango} \textbf{luwa} p-e u ko lïmndï ndï=ala | \gls 2SG just jungle thing 3PL which place be{-dep} 2SG just eye 3PL=see | \glt `Where are your jungle properties? Do you see them?’

Knowledge Point: Commands (or requests) are, generally, built around an \isi{imperative} form of a verb (\sectref{sec:4.7}). Imperative sentences may contain an expressed subject (typically a second \isi{person} \isi{pronoun}), but, as in all sentence types, it is possible for the subject to be omitted. Examples \REF{ex:syntax:67} through \REF{ex:syntax:71} illustrate how second \isi{person} \isi{pronoun}s may be included in \isi{imperative} sentences.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{U} nul \textbf{man}! | \gll \textbf{u} nï=ul ma-\textbf{n} | \gls 2SG 1SG=with go-IMP | \glt `Go with me!’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Un} maya wa \textbf{nayn}! | \gll \textbf{un} ma=iya wa na-i-\textbf{n} | \gls 2PL 3SG.OBJ=toward village DETR-come-IMP | \glt `Come home to her!’

Knowledge Point: In the \isi{imperative} sentences shown in \REF{ex:syntax:72}, \REF{ex:syntax:73}, and \REF{ex:syntax:74}, the second \isi{person} subject is not expressed.
Content 1: \gsrc Amun \textbf{man}! | \gll amun ma-\textbf{n} | \gls now go-IMP | \glt `Go now!’
Content 2: \gsrc Unji mat \textbf{indan}! | \gll u-nji ma=tï inda-\textbf{n} | \gls 2SG-POSS 3SG.OBJ=take walk-IMP | \glt `Carry your [child] around!’
Content 3: \gsrc Unji al kwa ndawa ka \textbf{lowon}! | \gll u-nji al kwa anda-awa ka lo-wo-\textbf{n} | \gls 2SG-POSS net one SG.DIST-INT in IRR-sleep-IMP | \glt `Sleep in that other mosquito net of yours!’

Knowledge Point: \isi{Third person imperative}s (or \isi{jussive}s) are also possible. These are no different from prototypical second \isi{person} imperatives: they, too, contain a verb with the \isi{imperative} \isi{suffix}; the only difference is that the \isi{command} is issued to a third \isi{person} referent. Sentences \REF{ex:syntax:75}, \REF{ex:syntax:76}, and \REF{ex:syntax:77} are examples of \isi{third person imperative}s in Ulwa.
Content 1: \gsrc Mï \textbf{lan}! | \gll mï la-\textbf{n} | \gls 3SG.SUBJ eat-IMP | \glt `Let him eat!’
Content 2: \gsrc Ndï \textbf{wutïnin}! | \gll ndï wutï-ni-\textbf{n} | \gls 3PL leg-beat-IMP | \glt `Let them dance!’
Content 3: \gsrc Kalingana kalilïta mï \textbf{man}! | \gll Kalingana kali-lï-ta mï ma-\textbf{n} | \gls [name] send-put{-cond} 3SG.SUBJ go-IMP | \glt `Send Kalingana and he’ll go!’

Knowledge Point: \isi{First person imperative}s (or \isi{hortative}s) are possible as well, but only for \isi{non-singular} \isi{inclusive} forms. That is, at least one addressee must be included in the \isi{exhortation}. Sentences \REF{ex:syntax:78}, \REF{ex:syntax:79}, and \REF{ex:syntax:80} are examples of \isi{first person imperative}s in Ulwa.
Content 1: \gsrc Ngunan \textbf{lan}! | \gll ngunan la-\textbf{n} | \gls 1DU.INCL eat-IMP | \glt `Let’s eat!’
Content 2: \gsrc Unan \textbf{ndïlan}! | \gll unan ndï=la-\textbf{n} | \gls 1PL.INCL 3PL=eat-IMP | \glt `Let’s eat them!’
Content 3: \gsrc Una \textbf{man}! | \gll unan ma-\textbf{n} | \gls 1PL.INCL go-IMP | \glt `Let’s go!’

Knowledge Point: Indeed, the only referents that cannot be the subjects of \isi{imperative}s are first \isi{person} non-\isi{inclusive} forms -- that is, first \isi{person} \isi{singular}, first \isi{person} \isi{dual} \isi{exclusive}, and first \isi{person} \isi{plural} \isi{exclusive}, as illustrated by the ungrammatical sentences \REF{ex:syntax:81} and \REF{ex:syntax:82}. Similar constructions containing these pronominal forms, however, can be created with the \isi{irrealis} \isi{suffix}, as illustrated by sentences \REF{ex:syntax:83} and \REF{ex:syntax:84}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï \textbf{lan}! | \gll nï la\textbf{-n} | \gls 1SG eat-IMP | \glt `Let me eat!’
Content 2: \gsrc An \textbf{lan}! | \gll an la-\textbf{n} | \gls 1PL.EXCL eat-IMP | \glt `Let’s eat!’
Content 3: \gsrc Nï \textbf{landa}. | \gll nï la-\textbf{nda} | \gls 1SG eat-IRR | \glt `I should eat.’
Content 4: \gsrc An \textbf{landa}. | \gll an la-\textbf{nda} | \gls 1PL.EXCL eat-IRR | \glt `We should eat.’

Knowledge Point: The issue is, however, complicated, since, in casual speech, speakers commonly drop verbal endings, especially of \isi{irrealis} verb forms. Thus, among the collected texts there are examples of \isi{irrealis} clauses with, for example, 1\textsc{sg} subjects that do appear to employ the \isi{imperative} \isi{suffix} -n `\textsc{imp}’, as in \REF{ex:syntax:85}. I consider it more likely, however, that this \isi{alveolar} \isi{nasal} represents an abbreviated form of the \isi{irrealis} \isi{suffix} -na {\textasciitilde} -nda `\textsc{irr}’.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï ma ndïn \textbf{lun}. | \gll nï ma ndï=n lo-\textbf{n[da]} | \gls 1SG go 3PL=OBL cut-IRR | \glt `I will go and plant them.’

Knowledge Point: Thus, some clauses containing \isi{irrealis} verbs may be functionally equivalent to \isi{imperative}s, and they may therefore be translated as such in \ili{English}, as in the first translation of examples \REF{ex:syntax:86}, \REF{ex:syntax:87}, and \REF{ex:syntax:88}.
Content 1: \gsrc U \textbf{landa}! | \gll u la-\textbf{nda} | \gls 2SG eat-IRR | \glt (a) ‘Eat!’
Content 2: \gsrc Asa u mat \textbf{nïnanda}! | \gll asa u ma=tï nï=na-\textbf{nda} | \gls no 2SG 3SG.OBJ=take 1SG=give-IRR | \glt (a) ‘No, give it to me!’
Content 3: \gsrc Kïkal misimisi \textbf{ngawananda}! | \gll kïkal misimisi nga=wana-\textbf{nda} | \gls ear story SG.PROX=feel-IRR | \glt (a) ‘Listen to this story!’

Knowledge Point: This use of the \isi{irrealis} \isi{suffix} also applies to \isi{third person imperative}s \REF{ex:syntax:89} and \isi{first person imperative}s, whether \isi{dual} \REF{ex:syntax:90} or \isi{plural} \REF{ex:syntax:91}.
Content 1: \gsrc Mï \textbf{landa}! | \gll mï la-\textbf{nda} | \gls 3SG.SUBJ eat-IRR | \glt (a) ‘Let him eat!’
Content 2: \gsrc Ngunan \textbf{mana}! | \gll ngunan ma-\textbf{na} | \gls 1DU.INCL go-IRR | \glt (a) ‘We shall go.’
Content 3: \gsrc Una \textbf{mana}! | \gll unan ma-\textbf{na} | \gls 1PL.INCL go-IRR | \glt (a) ‘We must go.’

Knowledge Point: The \isi{modal adverb} kop ‘please’ (\sectref{sec:8.2.5}) may be used to soften a \isi{command}, as seen in sentences \REF{ex:syntax:92} and \REF{ex:syntax:93}, which contain \isi{imperative} verb forms (\sectref{sec:4.7}).
Content 1: \gsrc I apa i \textbf{kop} lamap we un \textbf{man}! | \gll i apa i \textbf{kop} la-ama-p we un ma-\textbf{n} | \gls go.PFV house go.PFV please IRR-eat-PFV then 2PL go-IMP | \glt `Come, come to the house, eat, and then go!’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Kop} \textbf{malakan}! | \gll \textbf{kop} ma=la-ka-\textbf{n} | \gls please 3PL=IRR-let-IMP | \glt `Just leave him!’

Knowledge Point: Another method of softening a \isi{command} is using a \isi{conditional} verb form – that is, one with the ending -ta ‘\textsc{cond}’ (\sectref{sec:4.12}, \sectref{sec:13.5}), as illustrated by \REF{ex:syntax:94}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï umbe Supam ul \textbf{mata} mï maya ata mana. | \gll nï umbe Supam ul ma-\textbf{ta} mï ma=iya ata ma-na | \gls 1SG tomorrow [name] with go-COND 3SG.SUBJ 3SG.OBJ=toward up go-IRR | \glt `I’ll go with Supam tomorrow and she’ll climb it [= a tree].’

Knowledge Point: In the story from which sentence \REF{ex:syntax:94} is taken, a mother is addressing her children, including Supam. While the literal meaning of the first clause is ‘if I go with Supam …’, it has the \isi{pragmatic} value of ‘Supam, you shall go with me …!’ This \isi{imperative} use of a typically \isi{dependent} \isi{conditional} clause may thus be taken as an example of \isi{insubordination} \citep{Evans2007}. Further examples of \isi{conditional sentence}s functioning as softened commands are given in \REF{ex:syntax:95}, \REF{ex:syntax:96}, and \REF{ex:syntax:97}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï umbe Supam ul \textbf{mata} mï maya ata mana. | \gll nï umbe Supam ul ma-\textbf{ta} mï ma=iya ata ma-na | \gls 1SG tomorrow [name] with go-COND 3SG.SUBJ 3SG.OBJ=toward up go-IRR | \glt `I’ll go with Supam tomorrow and she’ll climb it [= a tree].’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Nïlakata} nï mawl malanda! | \gll nï=la-ka-\textbf{ta} nï ma=ul ma=la-nda | \gls 1SG=IRR-let-COND 1SG 3SG.OBJ=with 3SG.OBJ=eat-IRR | \glt `Let me eat with him!’
Content 3: \gsrc Yena ngalat \textbf{ndïnata} ndï ndul lowope lunda! | \gll yena ngala=tï ndï=na-\textbf{ta} ndï ndï=ul lo-wo-p-e lo-nda | \gls woman PL.PROX=take 3PL=give-COND 3PL 3PL=with IRR-sleep-PFV-DEP go-IRR | \glt `Give them these women, and they, having slept with them, will go!’
Content 4: \gsrc Kwa nïnji mol niya wa \textbf{ita} nï ko lïmndï mandïn. | \gll kwa nï-nji ma=ul nï=iya wa i-\textbf{ta} nï ko lïmndï ma=andï-na | \gls just 1SG-POSS 3SG.OBJ=with 1SG=toward village go.PFV-COND 1SG just eye 3SG.OBJ=see-IRR | \glt `If [you] come home to me with my [cousin], I will see her.’

Knowledge Point: The \isi{conditional} form may also be used with first \isi{person} commands (i.e., \isi{exhortation}s, \sectref{sec:13.2}). Often, only the \isi{protasis} (marked with the \isi{conditional} \isi{suffix} -ta ‘\textsc{cond}’) is expressed, leaving the \isi{apodosis} only implied, as in \REF{ex:syntax:98}.
Content 1: \gsrc Unan na kali wa alan \textbf{lïta}! | \gll unan na kali wa ala=n lï-\textbf{ta} | \gls 1PL.INCL talk send village PL.DIST=OBL put{-cond} | \glt `Let’s send a message to those villages!’

Knowledge Point: The \isi{modal adverb} kop ‘please’ may be used in conjunction with the \isi{conditional} verb form \REF{ex:syntax:99}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Kop} ma wa na \textbf{ndïtata} mata! | \gll \textbf{kop} ma wa na ndï=ta-\textbf{ta} ma-ta | \gls please go just talk 3PL=say-COND go-COND | \glt `Please, just go and tell stories!’

Knowledge Point: The form kop ‘please’ may be shortened to [ko], as in \REF{ex:syntax:100} and \REF{ex:syntax:101}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Ko} \textbf{ngapta} apa itap nji ngalembam pïn! | \gll \textbf{kop} nga=p-\textbf{ta} apa ita-p nji ngala=imbam p-n | \gls please SG.PROX=be{-cond} house build-PFV thing PL.PROX=under be-IMP | \glt `Please build a house here under these things!’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Ko} \textbf{amblakalampïta} lun! | \gll \textbf{kop} ambla=kalam=p-\textbf{ta} lo-n | \gls please PL.REFL=knowledge=COP-COND go-IMP | \glt `Please look after yourselves and go!’

Knowledge Point: Negative commands are formed with the \isi{prohibitive marker} wana \textsc{‘proh}’ or wanap \textsc{‘proh}’, which occurs along with an \isi{irrealis} verb form (and not with an \isi{imperative} verb form, \sectref{sec:8.3.1}). The prohibitive marker occurs in the same position as the standard \isi{negator} ango \textsc{‘neg}’, which is used to negate, for example, \isi{declarative} statements. In other words, the prohibitive marker follows the subject and precedes the verb \isi{phrase}, including any expressed object in \isi{transitive} clauses. As in \isi{positive} commands, it is common for the second \isi{person} subject of negative commands to be omitted, as in \REF{ex:syntax:102} and \REF{ex:syntax:103}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Wana} nunu nji tï ip lïp mana! | \gll \textbf{wana} nunu nji tï ip lï-p ma-na | \gls PROH every thing take nose put-PFV go-IRR | \glt `Don’t go destroying everything!’
Content 2: \gsrc Angani i \textbf{wanap} makape na! | \gll angani i \textbf{wanap} maka=p-e na | \gls behind go.PFV PROH thus=COP-DEP talk | \glt `Later, when [you] have come, do not [make] talk like this!’

Knowledge Point: Prohibitions, however, are not limited to second \isi{person} forms, but may apply to any \isi{person} or \isi{number}, as seen in examples \REF{ex:syntax:104} through \REF{ex:syntax:109}.
Content 1: \gsrc (U) \textbf{wana} nuwalinda! | \gll (u) \textbf{wana} nï=wali-nda | \gls (2SG) PROH 1SG=hit-IRR | \glt `Don’t hit me!’
Content 2: \gsrc Nï \textbf{wana} mana! | \gll nï \textbf{wana} ma-na | \gls 1SG PROH go-IRR | \glt `I shouldn’t go.’

Knowledge Point: Prohibitions may include the \isi{speculative} \isi{suffix} -t ‘\textsc{spec}’ on the \isi{irrealis} verb form (\sectref{sec:4.11}), as in examples \REF{ex:syntax:110} through \REF{ex:syntax:115}.
Content 1: \gsrc Tarambi \textbf{wana} apka nïklop ma ngaya \textbf{manat}! | \gll Tarambi \textbf{wana} apka nï=klop ma ngaya ma-na-\textbf{t} | \gls [name] PROH very 1SG=cross go far go-IRR-SPEC | \glt `Tarambi, don’t go completely bypass me and go far away!’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Wana} imba pïta niya \textbf{mbundanat}! | \gll \textbf{wana} imba p-ta nï=iya mbï-unda-na-\textbf{t} | \gls PROH night be{-cond} 1SG=toward here-go-IRR-SPEC | \glt `Don’t come around here to me at night!’

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{ex:syntax:115} also illustrates the use of the \isi{conditional} \isi{suffix} -ta ‘\textsc{cond}’ (\sectref{sec:4.12}). Although here it is used to show an actual condition (along with the \isi{speculative} \isi{suffix} on the final \isi{irrealis}-marked verb), it may also be used \isi{idiom}atically in prohibitions, presumably to present an implied \isi{apodosis} (i.e., ‘or else …!’), as in \REF{ex:syntax:116} and \REF{ex:syntax:117}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Wana} imba pïta niya \textbf{mbundanat}! | \gll \textbf{wana} imba p-ta nï=iya mbï-unda-na-\textbf{t} | \gls PROH night be{-cond} 1SG=toward here-go-IRR-SPEC | \glt `Don’t come around here to me at night!’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Wana} \textbf{mapta}! | \gll \textbf{wana} ma=p-\textbf{ta} | \gls PROH 3SG.OBJ=be{-cond} | \glt `Don’t live there!’
Content 3: \gsrc \textbf{Wana} \textbf{mbundata} inim lata \textbf{makapta}! | \gll \textbf{wana} mbï-unda\textbf{-ta} inim la-ta maka=p-\textbf{ta} | \gls PROH here-go-COND water eat{-cond} thus=COP-COND | \glt `Don’t come around here and drink beer like that!’

Knowledge Point: Negative \isi{declarative} sentences in Ulwa are typically readily identifiable by the \isi{negator} word ango ‘\textsc{neg’} (‘no, not’), which comes immediately after the subject NP (or, potentially, after other postnominal modifying elements, such as \isi{temporal adverb}s). Only when a subject NP is omitted can the \isi{negator} occur clause-initially. Examples \REF{ex:syntax:118} and \REF{ex:syntax:119} illustrate the variable ordering of ango ‘\textsc{neg}’ with other \isi{adverb}ial-like words.
Content 1: \gsrc Kolpe mï amun \textbf{ango} apa mayte. | \gll Kolpe mï amun \textbf{ango} apa ma=ita-e | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ now NEG house 3SG.OBJ=build-IPFV | \glt `Kolpe is not building the house now.’
Content 2: \gsrc Kolpe mï \textbf{ango} amun apa mayte. | \gll Kolpe mï \textbf{ango} amun apa ma=ita-e | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ NEG now house 3SG.OBJ=build-IPFV | \glt `Kolpe is not building the house now.’

Knowledge Point: Sentences \REF{ex:syntax:120} through \REF{ex:syntax:135} provide examples of negative constructions in Ulwa, all of which use the form ango ‘\textsc{neg}’. Many of these would be translated in \ili{English} (or many other languages) variously (e.g., with words such as ‘no one’, ‘not … anything’, ‘nothing’, etc.). Where relevant, parallel \isi{positive}-\isi{polarity} sentences are provided to illustrate contrasts.
Content 1: \gsrc Kwa \textbf{ango} nip. | \gll kwa \textbf{ango} ni-p | \gls one NEG die-PFV | \glt `No one died.’
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: Constructions that negate \isi{non-verbal predicate}s occasionally work the same as those that negate verbal \isi{predicate}s -- that is, \isi{non-verbal negation} may be expressed simply by means of the \isi{negator} ango ‘\textsc{neg}’ (see \sectref{sec:10.2} for \isi{non-verbal predication}). Both \is{classificatory predication} classificatory \REF{ex:syntax:136} and \is{possessive predication} possessive \REF{ex:syntax:137} \isi{predication} can be expressed with \isi{zero copula}. In both of these examples, \isi{negation} is accomplished by means of ango ‘\textsc{neg}’ alone.
Content 1: \gsrc Kolpe mï \textbf{ango} yana. | \gll Kolpe mï \textbf{ango} yana | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ NEG woman | \glt `Kolpe is not a woman.’
Content 2: \gsrc Nambi \textbf{ango} wandam ambi. | \gll nï-ambi \textbf{ango} wandam ambi | \gls 1SG-TOP NEG jungle big | \glt `As for me, I don’t have a big garden.’

Knowledge Point: Both \is{attributive predication} attributive \REF{ex:syntax:138} and \is{classificatory predication} classificatory \REF{ex:syntax:139} \isi{predication} can, alternatively, be expressed with the \isi{copular enclitic} =p ‘\textsc{cop}’. Here, too, \isi{negation} is marked by ango ‘\textsc{neg’}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Ango} anmap. | \gll \textbf{ango} anma=p | \gls NEG good=COP | \glt `[It] is not good.’
Content 2: \gsrc U \textbf{Ango} ulum ulwape. | \gll u \textbf{ango} ulum ulwa=p-e | \gls 2SG NEG palm nothing=COP-DEP | \glt `You had no lack of sago palms.’\footnote{This sentence offers a nice example of \isi{litotes}.} [ulwa014_50:02]’

Knowledge Point: More commonly, however, non-verbal \isi{negation} is accomplished by means of a \isi{clause-final negator}, either me ‘\textsc{neg’} or kom ‘\textsc{neg’} (sometimes kome ‘\textsc{neg}’, perhaps reflecting the \isi{dependent marker} -e ‘\textsc{dep}’). Typically, the \isi{clause-final negator} occurs in conjunction with the general \isi{negator} ango ‘\textsc{neg’} in its typical post-subject clause position. Thus non-verbal \isi{negation} in Ulwa is generally accomplished by means of a \isi{discontinuous} structure (cf. \ili{French} ne … pas). The \isi{discontinuous} structure ango … me ‘\textsc{neg}’ can be used to negate different kinds of \is{non-verbal predication} non-verbal \isi{predicate}s: \is{equative predication} equative \REF{ex:syntax:140}, \is{attributive predication} attributive \REF{ex:syntax:141}, \is{identificational predication} identificational \REF{ex:syntax:142}, \is{existential predication} existential \REF{ex:syntax:143}, and \is{classificatory predication} classificatory \REF{ex:syntax:144}; as well as different kinds of \isi{possessive predication}, as in \REF{ex:syntax:145} and \REF{ex:syntax:146}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï \textbf{ango} unji itom \textbf{me}. | \gll nï \textbf{ango} un-nji itom \textbf{me} | \gls 1SG NEG 2PL-POSS father NEG | \glt ‘I am not your father.’
Content 2: \gsrc Way \textbf{ango} ambi \textbf{me}. | \gll way \textbf{ango} ambi \textbf{me} | \gls turtle NEG big NEG | \glt `The turtle wasn’t big.’
Content 3: \gsrc \textbf{Ango} Taw \textbf{me}. | \gll \textbf{ango} Taw \textbf{me} | \gls NEG [place] NEG | \glt `[It] is not Taw.’
Content 4: \gsrc Ipka \textbf{ango} wambana ambi \textbf{me}. | \gll ipka \textbf{ango} wambana ambi \textbf{me} | \gls before NEG fish big NEG | \glt `Before, there weren’t any big fish.’
Content 5: \gsrc \textbf{Ango} nu luwa \textbf{me}. | \gll \textbf{ango} nu luwa \textbf{me} | \gls NEG close place NEG | \glt `[It] was not a close place.’
Content 6: \gsrc Unanambi \textbf{ango} unanji amba \textbf{me}. | \gll unan-ambi \textbf{ango} unan-nji amba \textbf{me} | \gls 1PL.INCL-TOP NEG 1PL.INCL-POSS mens.house NEG | \glt `As for us, we don’t have any magic.’
Content 7: \gsrc \textbf{Ango} unji \textbf{me}. | \gll \textbf{ango} u-nji \textbf{me} | \gls NEG 2SG-POSS NEG | \glt `[They] are not yours.’

Knowledge Point: Sentence \REF{ex:syntax:147} offers an example of the \isi{discontinuous negator} ango … me ‘\textsc{neg}’ being used with a \isi{nominalized verb phrase}.
Content 1: \gsrc Mï \textbf{ango} nan nïkapen \textbf{me}. | \gll mï \textbf{ango} na=n nï=kï-p-en \textbf{me} | \gls 3SG.SUBJ NEG talk=OBL 1SG=say-PFV-NMLZ NEG | \glt `She didn’t reply to me.’

Knowledge Point: It is interesting to note that there are also examples of clauses with \isi{nominalized verb phrase}s in which ango ‘\textsc{neg}’ is used without any \isi{clause-final negator}. The distinction between the presence and absence of such \isi{clause-final negator} could reflect a possible difference in \isi{scope} for the \isi{negator} ango ‘\textsc{neg’}: the presence of the \isi{clause-final negator} me ‘\textsc{neg’} (or kom ‘\textsc{neg’}) would thus suggest that the non-verbal \isi{predicate} (resulting from a \is{deverbalization} deverbalized verb) is being negated; and the absence of the \isi{clause-final negator} would suggest that the verb itself has been negated (before being \isi{deverbalized}). For example, \REF{ex:syntax:148} contains me \textsc{‘neg’}, whereas \REF{ex:syntax:149} lacks it.
Content 1: \gsrc Nambi \textbf{ango} alanji wandam \textbf{unden} \textbf{me}. | \gll nï-ambi \textbf{ango} ala-nji wandam unda-\textbf{en} \textbf{me} | \gls 1SG-TOP NEG PL.DIST-POSS jungle go-NMLZ NEG | \glt `As for me, I’m not one to go around in other people’s jungles.’
Content 2: \gsrc Nambi \textbf{ango} ndiya \textbf{mawnden}. | \gll nï-ambi \textbf{ango} ndï=iya ma=unda-\textbf{en} | \gls 1SG-TOP NEG 3PL=toward 3SG.OBJ=go-NMLZ | \glt `As for me, I don’t go around to them there.’

Knowledge Point: Perhaps \REF{ex:syntax:148} could thus be translated as something like ‘I am not a going-around-in-other-people’s-jungles person’, whereas \REF{ex:syntax:149} could be translated as something like ‘I am a not-going-around-to-them-there person’. \isi{Negative scope} is discussed further in \sectref{sec:13.3.4}. Alternatively, it is possible that the absence of \isi{clause-final negator}s with \isi{nominalized verb phrase}s simply reflects a more general optionality of such marking.
Content 1: \gsrc Nambi \textbf{ango} alanji wandam \textbf{unden} \textbf{me}. | \gll nï-ambi \textbf{ango} ala-nji wandam unda-\textbf{en} \textbf{me} | \gls 1SG-TOP NEG PL.DIST-POSS jungle go-NMLZ NEG | \glt `As for me, I’m not one to go around in other people’s jungles.’
Content 2: \gsrc Nambi \textbf{ango} ndiya \textbf{mawnden}. | \gll nï-ambi \textbf{ango} ndï=iya ma=unda-\textbf{en} | \gls 1SG-TOP NEG 3PL=toward 3SG.OBJ=go-NMLZ | \glt `As for me, I don’t go around to them there.’

Knowledge Point: Sentence \REF{ex:syntax:150} offers an example of the \isi{discontinuous negator} ango … me ‘\textsc{neg}’ being used with a \isi{relative clause}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Ango} kambe nji \textbf{me}. | \gll \textbf{ango} [kamb-e] nji \textbf{me} | \gls NEG [shun-DEP] thing NEG | \glt `[It] wasn’t something that [they] neglected.’

Knowledge Point: The other clause-final \isi{non-verbal negator} is kom ‘\textsc{neg’}. It, too, occurs in \isi{discontinuous} constructions with the \isi{negator} ango ‘\textsc{neg’}. Its use is illustrated in examples \REF{ex:syntax:151} through \REF{ex:syntax:154}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Ango} wala luwa \textbf{kom}. | \gll \textbf{ango} wala luwa \textbf{kom} | \gls NEG far.off place NEG | \glt `[It] is not a far-off place.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Ango} unanji amba \textbf{kom}. | \gll \textbf{ango} unan-nji amba \textbf{kom} | \gls NEG 1PL.INCL-POSS mens.house NEG | \glt `[It] is not our magic.’

Knowledge Point: Sometimes when \is{non-verbal predication} non-verbal \isi{predicate}s are negated, the \isi{clause-final negator} is used alone -- that is, the only \isi{negative} element in the sentence is me ‘\textsc{neg’} or kom ‘\textsc{neg’}, without ango ‘\textsc{neg’} being used at all.\footnote{This may resemble \isi{Jespersen’s Cycle} \citep{Dahl1979}, a \is{syntactic change} grammatical change whereby a preverbal \isi{negative} marker is replaced by a postverbal \isi{negative} marker via a stage of two-part \isi{negation} (again, as in \ili{French}). However, if in fact different diachronic stages are represented by the presence or absence of preverbal or postverbal \isi{negator}s, then their relative chronologies are not readily discernible. Discontinuous negation \is{discontinuous negator} is prevalent throughout the \ili{Keram} family, although the \isi{morphology} associated with it is perhaps not reconstructible. Given the rather rigid verb-final nature of these languages, the \isi{clause-final negator} may have more likely emerged via \isi{grammaticalization} of an older verb form. The particular history of this grammatical structure remains unknown. \ia{Jespersen, Otto}} Sentence \REF{ex:syntax:155} illustrates the use of me ‘\textsc{neg}’ alone (i.e., without ango ‘\textsc{neg’}) as a \isi{non-verbal negator}.
Content 1: \gsrc Un ini \textbf{me}. | \gll un ini \textbf{me} | \gls 2PL ground NEG | \glt `[It] is not your land.’

Knowledge Point: Sentences \REF{ex:syntax:156} and \REF{ex:syntax:157} demonstrate me ‘\textsc{neg}’ being used with the \isi{semantic}ally \isi{negative} word ulwa ‘nothing’, perhaps exemplifying a sort of \isi{negative concord}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Ulwa} \textbf{me}. | \gll \textbf{ulwa} \textbf{me} | \gls nothing NEG | \glt `[It] is nothing.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Ulwapen} \textbf{me} nï un ka naman. | \gll \textbf{ulwa}=p-en \textbf{me} nï u=n ka na-ma-n | \gls nothing=COP{-nmlz} NEG 1SG 2SG=OBL let DETR-go-IPFV | \glt `There’s nothing here, so I’m leaving you.’

Knowledge Point: It seems somewhat more common for the \isi{negator} kom ‘\textsc{neg’} (or kome ‘\textsc{neg’}) to be used alone -- that is, as the only \isi{negator} element in a \isi{negative} non-verbal clause. Sentences \REF{ex:syntax:158} through \REF{ex:syntax:161} illustrate the use of kom {\textasciitilde} kome ‘\textsc{neg}’ alone (i.e., without ango ‘\textsc{neg’}) as a \isi{non-verbal negator}.
Content 1: \gsrc Mïkï itïm \textbf{kome}. | \gll mïkï itïm \textbf{kome} | \gls tree.species trash NEG | \glt `[It] is not a swamp at all.’
Content 2: \gsrc Kwe wat u iyen \textbf{kom}. | \gll kwe wat u i-en \textbf{kom} | \gls one atop from go.PFV-NMLZ NEG | \glt `It wasn’t just one who came onto [it].’

Knowledge Point: Perhaps bearing on the diachronic question of these clause-final (and discontinuous) \isi{negator}s is the fact that it appears that kome ‘\textsc{neg’} itself may be separable into two parts, ko ‘just’ and me ‘\textsc{neg’}, which may surround the negated \is{non-verbal predication} non-verbal \isi{predicate}. In examples \REF{ex:syntax:162}, \REF{ex:syntax:163}, and \REF{ex:syntax:164}, the prenominal element is glossed as the \isi{modal adverb} ko ‘just, simply’, although it is formally identical to the \isi{indefinite} marker ko= ‘\textsc{indf’}. Its origin is unclear.
Content 1: \gsrc Un \textbf{ko} nïnji ankam \textbf{me}. | \gll un \textbf{ko} nï-nji ankam \textbf{me} | \gls 2PL just 1SG-POSS person NEG | \glt `You are not my people.’
Content 2: \gsrc Ngun \textbf{ko} ini anma \textbf{me}. | \gll ngun \textbf{ko} ini anma \textbf{me} | \gls 2DU just ground good NEG | \glt `You two, [it] is not good land.’
Content 3: \gsrc Nguna \textbf{ko} ndul amba kwe in wap \textbf{ko} ndïkalampen \textbf{me}. | \gll ngunan \textbf{ko} ndï=ul amba kwe in wap \textbf{ko} ndï=kalam=p-en \textbf{me} | \gls 1DU.INCL just 3PL=with mens.house one in be.PST just 3PL=knowledge=COP{-nmlz} NEG | \glt `We have not lived with them in even one men’s house nor [do we] know about them.’

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{ex:syntax:163} illustrates the peculiar behavior of kalam ‘knowledge, knowledgeable’, a \isi{loan} verb from \ili{Waran} that has taken on nominal/adjectival \is{adjective} features (\sectref{sec:5.4}). Here it is first \isi{verbalized} with the \isi{copular enclitic} =p ‘\textsc{cop’}, before receiving the \isi{nominalizing} \isi{suffix} -en ‘\textsc{nmlz’}. Finally, this \isi{nominalize}d form is negated with the \isi{non-verbal negator} me ‘\textsc{neg’}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ngun \textbf{ko} ini anma \textbf{me}. | \gll ngun \textbf{ko} ini anma \textbf{me} | \gls 2DU just ground good NEG | \glt `You two, [it] is not good land.’

Knowledge Point: Finally, it must be noted here that there are also instances in which me ‘\textsc{neg}’ is used alone without any apparent \isi{negative} sense. Such uses seem more common with \isi{adjective}s designating the greatness of someone or something, as in \REF{ex:syntax:165} and \REF{ex:syntax:166}.
Content 1: \gsrc E an namndu nïpat \textbf{me}! | \gll e an namndu nïpat \textbf{me} | \gls ay 1PL.EXCL pig giant NEG | \glt `Ay, we [had] really giant pigs!’
Content 2: \gsrc Ambi ngata nda yangle \textbf{me} kenmbu nïpat. | \gll ambi ngata anda yangle \textbf{me} kenmbu nïpat | \gls big grand SG.DIST strong NEG heavy giant | \glt `That big huge [child] was very strong, terribly heavy.’

Knowledge Point: Perhaps sentences such as \REF{ex:syntax:165} and \REF{ex:syntax:166} should be taken to mean, for example, ‘not [merely] giant, [but rather] really, really giant’. Alternatively, they could perhaps be \is{irony} ironical statements.
Content 1: \gsrc E an namndu nïpat \textbf{me}! | \gll e an namndu nïpat \textbf{me} | \gls ay 1PL.EXCL pig giant NEG | \glt `Ay, we [had] really giant pigs!’
Content 2: \gsrc Ambi ngata nda yangle \textbf{me} kenmbu nïpat. | \gll ambi ngata anda yangle \textbf{me} kenmbu nïpat | \gls big grand SG.DIST strong NEG heavy giant | \glt `That big huge [child] was very strong, terribly heavy.’

Knowledge Point: In prohibitions (i.e., \isi{negative} \isi{command}s), the regular \isi{negator} ango ‘\textsc{neg’} is not used at all, but rather the prohibitive marker wana {\textasciitilde} wanap ‘\textsc{proh’} is used, as in \REF{ex:syntax:167}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Wanap} apka nïklop mana! | \gll \textbf{wanap} apka nï=klop ma-na | \gls PROH very 1SG=cross go-IRR | \glt `Don’t go and bypass me completely!’

Knowledge Point: An interesting fact about Ulwa \isi{negation} concerns the \isi{scope} of the \isi{negator}. The tendency in Ulwa is to place ango ‘\textsc{neg}’ within the first clause of \isi{multiclausal construction}s, even when the \isi{scope} of \isi{negation} is smaller than the whole series of clauses. In other words, a subsequent clause or clausal element may be negated, without any \isi{negation} implied concerning the clause in which ango ‘\textsc{neg}’ occurs, as illustrated in examples \REF{ex:syntax:168} through \REF{ex:syntax:170}.
Content 1: \gsrc An \textbf{ango} apa mbïlop mbïwap. | \gll an \textbf{ango} apa mbï-lo-p mbï-wap | \gls 1PL.EXCL NEG house here-go-PFV here-be.PST | \glt `We came home, but didn’t stay.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Ango} mat mïnjikan kïna: … | \gll \textbf{ango} ma=tï mïnjika=n kï-na | \gls NEG 3SG.OBJ=take speech=OBL say-IRR | \glt `Having gotten it, [they] wouldn’t say [the following]: …’

Knowledge Point: This rather early placement of ango ‘\textsc{neg}’ occurs in \isi{conditional} statements as well -- that is, the \isi{negator} may occur within the \isi{protasis}, even when the verbal element to be negated belongs in the \isi{apodosis}. In each of the \isi{conditional} statements in \REF{ex:syntax:171}, \REF{ex:syntax:172}, and \REF{ex:syntax:173}, ango ‘\textsc{neg}’ occurs within the \isi{protasis}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Ango} maka apwanam mapta inim landa. | \gll \textbf{ango} maka apwanam ma=p-ta inim la-nda | \gls NEG thus side.of.house 3SG.OBJ=be{-cond} water eat-IRR | \glt `As long as [she] is staying at the side of the house, [a recent mother] may not drink water.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Ango} mat ita nduwe malanda. | \gll \textbf{ango} ma=tï i-ta ndï-we ma=la-nda | \gls NEG 3SG.OBJ=take go.PFV-COND 3PL-PART.INT 3SG.OBJ=eat-IRR | \glt `If [he] brings it, they will not eat it alone.’
Content 3: \gsrc \textbf{Ango} amunpïta ikali masinate. | \gll \textbf{ango} amun=p-ta i-kali ma=si-na-t-e | \gls NEG now=COP{-cond} hand-send 3SG.OBJ=push-IRR-SPEC-DEP | \glt `If [a baby] is still very young, [then fathers] will not hold it.’

Knowledge Point: In the two \isi{conditional} prohibitive statements given in \REF{ex:syntax:174} and \REF{ex:syntax:175}, the \isi{negative} marker wana ‘\textsc{proh’} occurs in the \isi{protasis}, even though the \isi{negation} properly occurs in the \isi{apodosis}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Wana} ambipïta wa lolop ala wandam pïta alanji nji landa! | \gll \textbf{wana} ambi=p-ta wa lolop ala wandam p-ta ala-nji nji la-nda | \gls PROH big=COP{-cond} just just PL.DIST jungle be{-cond} PL.DIST-POSS thing eat-IRR | \glt `When [you] are grown and are just [going around] in other people’s gardens, don’t eat their things!’
Content 2: \gsrc A un \textbf{wana} apa mapta luke natana! | \gll a un \textbf{wana} apa ma=p-ta luke na-ta-na | \gls INTERJ 2PL PROH house 3SG.OBJ=be{-cond} too DETR-say-IRR | \glt `Hey, if you’re in the house, don’t talk either!’

Knowledge Point: It is relatively uncommon to answer ‘yes’ or ‘no’ to \isi{question}s in Ulwa: rather, interlocutors tend to respond with full answers or \isi{paralinguistic gesture}s (such as head movements) or \isi{interjection}s (such as m ‘hm!’). It is nevertheless possible to use the word ase ‘no’ (sometimes realized as [asa]), whether as a \isi{response} to a \isi{question}, or as a simple denial (without any \isi{question} necessarily having been posed). Sentences \REF{ex:syntax:176} through \REF{ex:syntax:179} provide examples of its use.
Content 1: \gsrc Ndï man nan nït \textbf{ase}. | \gll ndï ma=n na=n nï=ta \textbf{ase} | \gls 3PL 3SG.OBJ=OBL talk=OBL 1SG=say no | \glt `They told me “no”.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Asa} mï mïnjikan ngunankap: … | \gll \textbf{asa} mï mïnjika=n ngunan=kï-p | \gls no 3SG.SUBJ speech=OBL 1DU.INCL=say-PFV | \glt `No, he said the following to us: …’

Knowledge Point: In Ulwa, \isi{direct discourse} is constructed around at least two separate clauses: one containing the quoted utterance (typically the second clause) and one reporting who uttered it (typically the first clause). \isi{Direct discourse} constructions are thus of the form: ‘speaker says/said: “[what that person says/said]”’, as in \REF{ex:syntax:179a}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï mat ndï amun up. | \gll nï ma=ta ndï amun u-p | \gls 1SG 3SG.OBJ=say 3PL now put-PFV | \glt `I said: “They’ve only now planted (them).”’

Subsection: Intransitive uses of verbs of speaking\label{sec:13.4.1
Knowledge Point: In examples \REF{ex:syntax:180}, \REF{ex:syntax:181}, and \REF{ex:syntax:182}, the verb of speaking ta- ‘say’ or kï- ‘say’ is used \isi{intransitive}ly. The form [na], when present, is glossed as the \isi{detransitivizing} marker (\sectref{sec:13.8.2}), although the argument could be made that it is the noun na ‘talk’ functioning as the first half of a \isi{compound verb} form. Since the verb of speaking is often \isi{transitive}, however, the analysis of [na] here as the \isi{detransitivizing} marker na- \textsc{‘detr’} is preferred, since the form seems to be helping to \is{valency reduction} reduce the \isi{valency} of the verb.
Content 1: \gsrc Awal imba pe una \textbf{natap}. | \gll awal imba p-e unan \textbf{na-ta}-p | \gls yesterday night be{-dep} 1PL.INCL DETR-say-PFV | \glt `Last night we talked.’
Content 2: \gsrc Inom mï \textbf{nakap}. | \gll inom mï \textbf{na-kï-p} | \gls mother 3SG.SUBJ DETR-say-PFV | \glt `Mother spoke.’
Content 3: Not found

Subsection: Transitive uses of verbs of speaking\label{sec:13.4.2
Knowledge Point: It is, however, much more common for the verb of speaking to be \isi{transitive}, taking as the object either the thing said or the person addressed. In examples \REF{ex:syntax:183} through \REF{ex:syntax:186}, the object of the verb is the thing said. Note that the \isi{detransitivizing} marker na- \textsc{‘detr’} is not present in these \isi{transitive} clauses. The noun na ‘talk’, however, may occur.
Content 1: \gsrc Min na kuma \textbf{tap}. | \gll min na kuma \textbf{ta}-p | \gls 3DU talk some say-PFV | \glt `The two planned something.’
Content 2: \gsrc Ndï ndïnap atwana \textbf{kïna}. | \gll ndï ndï=nap atwana \textbf{kï}-na | \gls 3PL 3PL=for question say-IRR | \glt `They will ask about them.’

Subsection: Transitive uses of verbs of speaking\label{sec:13.4.2
Knowledge Point: Example \REF{ex:syntax:186} illustrates how reported \isi{question}s can be expressed: namely, one uses the \isi{verb phrase} ‘say a question’, where ‘question’ is the object of the verb of speaking.
Content 1: \gsrc Ndï ndïnap atwana \textbf{kïna}. | \gll ndï ndï=nap atwana \textbf{kï}-na | \gls 3PL 3PL=for question say-IRR | \glt `They will ask about them.’

Subsection: Transitive uses of verbs of speaking\label{sec:13.4.2
Knowledge Point: Often, the verb of speaking takes as an object the thing said, without there being much \isi{semantic} value to this object. That is, the object (always a bare \textsc{3sg} \isi{object-marker} \isi{clitic}) functions as an \isi{expletive}, as in examples \REF{ex:syntax:187} through \REF{ex:syntax:191}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï \textbf{mat} a! | \gll nï \textbf{ma=ta} a | \gls 1SG 3SG.OBJ=say ah | \glt `I said, “ah!”’
Content 2: \gsrc Nï lïmndï minlïpe \textbf{mat}: … | \gll nï lïmndï min=lï-p-e \textbf{ma=ta} | \gls 1SG eye 3DU=put-PFV-DEP 3SG.OBJ=say | \glt `I saw the two of them and said: …’

Subsection: Transitive uses of verbs of speaking\label{sec:13.4.2
Knowledge Point: As illustrated by examples such as \REF{ex:syntax:191}, among others, it is common for verbs of speaking (or at least the verb ta- ‘say’) to be \isi{defective} -- that is, the \isi{verb stem} is often left unmarked for \isi{TAM} (and loses its \isi{stem}-final \isi{vowel}), thus being pronounced as just [t]. This occurs especially in situations in which the object of \isi{speech} is an \isi{expletive} (or \isi{dummy}) object.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï lïmndï minlïpe \textbf{mat}: … | \gll nï lïmndï min=lï-p-e \textbf{ma=ta} | \gls 1SG eye 3DU=put-PFV-DEP 3SG.OBJ=say | \glt `I saw the two of them and said: …’

Subsection: Transitive uses of verbs of speaking\label{sec:13.4.2
Knowledge Point: The role of the object of the \isi{transitive} verb of speaking, however, need not be the thing spoken, but may instead be the person addressed, as in \REF{ex:syntax:192}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï \textbf{nan mat} nï ango makïke lunda. | \gll nï \textbf{na=n} ma=\textbf{ta} nï ango ma=kïke lo-nda | \gls 1SG talk=OBL 3SG.OBJ=say 1SG NEG 3SG.OBJ=throw go-IRR | \glt `I told her: “I won’t sell it.”’

Subsection: Transitive uses of verbs of speaking\label{sec:13.4.2
Knowledge Point: In such constructions, the word na ‘talk’ is often present before the \isi{object marker}. This word may or may not be followed by the \isi{oblique marker} =n ‘\textsc{obl}’. When this marker is present, then the construction is analyzed as a clause that consists of a \isi{transitive} verb taking the person addressed as its \isi{direct object} and an \isi{oblique} \isi{phrase} composed of the word na ‘talk’ plus the \isi{oblique marker} (i.e., literally ‘tell [someone] with/by means of speech/talk’). In examples \REF{ex:syntax:193} through \REF{ex:syntax:199}, the verbs ta- ‘say’ and kï- ‘say’ are used \isi{transitive}ly, taking as an object the person addressed. The \isi{verb phrase} follows the \isi{oblique} \isi{phrase} na=n ‘with talk’.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï \textbf{nan ndït} nga unji. | \gll nï \textbf{na=n} ndï=\textbf{ta} nga un-nji | \gls 1SG talk=OBL 3PL=say SG.PROX 2PL-POSS | \glt `I said to them: “This is yours.”’
Content 2: \gsrc Mï \textbf{nan minte} ngun naman! | \gll mï \textbf{na=n} min=\textbf{ta}-e ngun na-ma-n | \gls 3SG.SUBJ talk=OBL 3DU=say-DEP 2DU DETR-go-IMP | \glt `He told the two of them: “Go!”’

Subsection: Transitive uses of verbs of speaking\label{sec:13.4.2
Knowledge Point: Dependent marking \is{dependent marker} is not necessary in such \isi{reported speech} constructions, although it may be possible, as in \REF{ex:syntax:199}.
Content 1: \gsrc Mï \textbf{nan minte} ngun naman! | \gll mï \textbf{na=n} min=\textbf{ta}-e ngun na-ma-n | \gls 3SG.SUBJ talk=OBL 3DU=say-DEP 2DU DETR-go-IMP | \glt `He told the two of them: “Go!”’

Subsection: Transitive uses of verbs of speaking\label{sec:13.4.2
Knowledge Point: Since the word na ‘talk’ functions as the \isi{head noun} of its own \isi{oblique} \isi{phrase} in these constructions, it is possible for it to be modified by an \isi{adjective} \REF{ex:syntax:200}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ndï \textbf{na ilumnï} ukïnat. | \gll ndï \textbf{na} \textbf{ilum=nï} u=kï-na-t | \gls 3PL talk little=OBL 2SG=say-IRR-SPEC | \glt `They might tell you a little story.’

Subsection: Transitive uses of verbs of speaking\label{sec:13.4.2
Knowledge Point: When the \isi{oblique marker} is absent, on the other hand, then the construction is analyzed as a \is{compound verb} \isi{compound} \isi{verb phrase} in which the nominal element occurs before the object (that is, they are \isi{separable verb} constructions; see \sectref{sec:9.2.1}).\footnote{In certain situations, however, it is impossible to tell whether the form [na] contains the \isi{enclitic} =n ‘\textsc{obl}’ or not: if [na] is followed by a word that begins with /n-/ or /nd-/, then the sequence /nn/ -- if ever present -- would \isi{degeminate} to [n].} In examples \REF{ex:syntax:201} through \REF{ex:syntax:206}, the verbs ta- ‘say’ and kï- ‘say’ are used \isi{transitive}ly, taking as an object the person addressed. Although the word na ‘talk’ is present, it does not take the \isi{oblique marker} =n `\textsc{obl}’. Accordingly, these sentences are interpreted as containing \isi{compound} \isi{verb phrase}s, in which the nominal component is separate from the \isi{verb stem}, occurring before the object.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï \textbf{na} \textbf{makïna} ase. | \gll nï \textbf{na} ma=\textbf{kï}-na ase | \gls 1SG talk 3SG.OBJ=say-IRR no | \glt `I will tell him “no”.’
Content 2: \gsrc Nï ango angos \textbf{na} \textbf{ukïnate}. | \gll nï ango angos \textbf{na} u=\textbf{kï}-na-t-e | \gls 1SG NEG what talk 2SG=say-IRR-SPEC-DEP | \glt `I don’t have anything to tell you.’

Subsection: Transitive uses of verbs of speaking\label{sec:13.4.2
Knowledge Point: In another version of \isi{transitive} clauses based on the verbs ta- ‘say’ and kï- ‘say’, an \isi{expletive} pronominal \isi{clitic} ma= ‘\textsc{3sg.obj}’ is used in place of na ‘talk’ and receives the \isi{oblique marker} =n ‘\textsc{obl}’. The literal meaning of these constructions could be rendered as ‘tell [someone] with it’ (with ‘speech’ understood as the \isi{antecedent} of ‘it’). This construction is illustrated by examples \REF{ex:syntax:207} through \REF{ex:syntax:211}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï \textbf{man} \textbf{ngunte}: … | \gll nï \textbf{ma=n} ngun=\textbf{ta}-e | \gls 1SG 3SG.OBJ=OBL 2DU=say-DEP | \glt `I told you two: …’
Content 2: \gsrc Nï \textbf{man unate}: … | \gll nï \textbf{ma=n} u=na-\textbf{ta}-e | \gls 1SG 3SG.OBJ=OBL 2SG=talk-say-DEP | \glt `I’m telling you: …’

Subsection: Transitive uses of verbs of speaking\label{sec:13.4.2
Knowledge Point: Example \REF{ex:syntax:211} illustrates the \isi{compound verb} form na-ta ‘say talk’ co-occurring with the \isi{oblique}-marked \isi{expletive} construction ma=n ‘with it’.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï \textbf{man unate}: … | \gll nï \textbf{ma=n} u=na-\textbf{ta}-e | \gls 1SG 3SG.OBJ=OBL 2SG=talk-say-DEP | \glt `I’m telling you: …’

Knowledge Point: A topic spoken about can be referred to as a \isi{phrase} consisting of the topic, \is{possession} possessive marking, and the word na ‘talk’ (literally something like ‘X’s story’, where X can be any kind of referent: a person, thing, or concept). Various means of indicating \isi{possession} can be used in such constructions: the possessive \isi{suffix} \textit{{}-nji} ‘\textsc{poss’} \textsc{\REF{ex:syntax:212}}, the \isi{oblique} \isi{enclitic} =n ‘\textsc{obl’} \textsc{\REF{ex:syntax:213}}, or a \isi{non-subject} pronominal \REF{ex:syntax:214} or \isi{deictic} \REF{ex:syntax:215} form.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Manji na} latane. | \gll \textbf{ma-nji} \textbf{na} ala=ta-n-e | \gls 3SG.OBJ-POSS talk PL.DIST=say-IPFV-DEP | \glt `[We] were talking about her.’
Content 2: \gsrc Nï \textbf{ini man na} tane Wore un ango wap? | \gll nï \textbf{ini} \textbf{ma=n} \textbf{na} ta-n-e Wore un ango wap | \gls 1SG ground 3SG.OBJ=OBL talk say-IPFV-DEP [place] 2PL which be.PST | \glt `When I was talking about the land, where were you, [people from] Wore?’
Content 3: \gsrc Nï amun maka \textbf{lamndu wonmbi ma na} tana manen. | \gll nï amun maka \textbf{lamndu} \textbf{wonmbi} \textbf{ma} \textbf{na} ta-na ma-n-en | \gls 1SG now thus pig tusk 3SG.OBJ talk say-IRR go-IPFV-NMLZ | \glt `Now I’m thus going to tell the story of the boar tusk.’
Content 4: \gsrc Sande ndan \textbf{apa nda na} te. | \gll Sande anda=n \textbf{apa} \textbf{anda} \textbf{na} ta-e | \gls Sunday SG.DIST=OBL house SG.DIST talk say-DEP | \glt `Last Sunday, [he] was talking about that church.’

Knowledge Point: If there is a person addressed in such constructions, then this person typically occurs as the \isi{direct object} of the verb of speaking and the topic is included as an \isi{oblique} \isi{phrase} marked by =n ‘\textsc{obl}’ following the word na ‘talk’, as in \REF{ex:syntax:216}, \REF{ex:syntax:217}, and \REF{ex:syntax:218}. The \is{possession} possessive marker does not seem to be necessary.
Content 1: \gsrc Ndï \textbf{isi nan} antane. | \gll ndï \textbf{isi} \textbf{na=n} an=ta-n-e | \gls 3PL salt talk=OBL 1PL.EXCL=say-IPFV-DEP | \glt `They were asking us about salt.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Ndunduma nan} nïte nï mat: … | \gll \textbf{ndunduma} \textbf{na=n} nï=ta-e nï ma=ta | \gls ancestor talk=OBL 1SG=say-DEP 1SG 3SG.OBJ=say | \glt `When [they] asked me about [their] ancestors, I said: …’
Content 3: \gsrc Nïnji ulum \textbf{ndï nan} nïkap. | \gll nï-nji ulum \textbf{ndï} \textbf{na=n} nï=kï-p | \gls 1SG-POSS palm 3PL talk=OBL 1SG=say-PFV | \glt `[She] told me about my sago palms.’

Knowledge Point: In casual speech, the verb of speaking is sometimes omitted, presumably implied by the word na ‘talk’ plus the \isi{oblique marker} =n ‘\textsc{obl}’ (or by the \isi{expletive} \isi{oblique} \isi{phrase} ma=n ‘with it’), as in \REF{ex:syntax:219} and \REF{ex:syntax:220}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï \textbf{nan}: … | \gll nï \textbf{na=n} | \gls 1SG talk=OBL | \glt `I said: …’
Content 2: \gsrc Nï wolka \textbf{man} Carobim u nul man! | \gll nï wolka \textbf{ma=n} Carobim u nï=ul ma-n | \gls 1SG again 3SG.OBJ=OBL [name] 2SG 1SG=with go-IMP | \glt `I in turn [told] Carobim: “Go with me!”’

Knowledge Point: Sometimes \isi{speech} is reported without any word of speaking at all to signal the quotation -- that is, there is neither the verb ta- ‘say’ or kï- ‘say’ nor the noun na ‘talk’ or an \isi{expletive} in its place. Such quotations are often signaled by \isi{intonation} or by \isi{paralinguistic sound}s or \is{paralinguistic gesture} gestures. Often they follow a \isi{phrase} of ‘seeing’, which may be used \isi{idiom}atically to signal thought or reflection, as in \REF{ex:syntax:221} and \REF{ex:syntax:222}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï \textbf{lïmndï ndala} ungusuwata wombïn ambi nda. | \gll nï \textbf{lïmndï} \textbf{ndï=ala} un-ngusuwata wombïn ambi anda | \gls 1SG eye 3PL=see 2PL-poor work big SG.DIST | \glt `I saw them [and said:] “You poor things – that’s big work.”’
Content 2: \gsrc Itom ndï \textbf{lïmndï anala a} anji nungol ala ambi nape. | \gll itom ndï \textbf{lïmndï} \textbf{an=ala} \textbf{a} an-nji nungol ala ambi na-p-e | \gls father 3PL eye 1PL.EXCL=see ah 1PL.EXCL-POSS child PL.DIST big DETR-be{-dep} | \glt `[Our] fathers saw us [and said:] “Ah! Our sons have gotten big.”’

Knowledge Point: As illustrated by example \REF{ex:syntax:222}, the \isi{exclamation} a ‘ah!’ often signals \isi{speech} as well (\sectref{sec:8.3.3}). It typically belongs at the end of a \isi{prosodic unit}, with the rest of the quoted \isi{speech} continuing at the start of the subsequent \isi{prosodic unit}.
Content 1: \gsrc Itom ndï \textbf{lïmndï anala a} anji nungol ala ambi nape. | \gll itom ndï \textbf{lïmndï} \textbf{an=ala} \textbf{a} an-nji nungol ala ambi na-p-e | \gls father 3PL eye 1PL.EXCL=see ah 1PL.EXCL-POSS child PL.DIST big DETR-be{-dep} | \glt `[Our] fathers saw us [and said:] “Ah! Our sons have gotten big.”’

Knowledge Point: When recounting stories, people may also omit a verb of speaking to make the action livelier \REF{ex:syntax:223}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ne may tata! | \gll na-i ma=i tata | \gls DETR-go.PFV 3SG.OBJ=go.PFV papa | \glt `[He] went, went to him [and said:] “Papa!”’

Knowledge Point: Also, when conversations are recounted, the back-and-forth between two or more quoted speakers need not contain verbs of speaking between each turn, as in \REF{ex:syntax:224}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï atwana mat a un ango luwa? An ma we ndatïna le. Ande nol! | \gll nï atwana ma=ta a un ango luwa an ma we anda=tï-na lo-e ande na-lo | \gls 1SG question 3SG.OBJ=say ah 2PL which place 1PL.EXCL go sago SG.DIST=take-IRR go-DEP ok DETR-go | \glt `I asked her: “Ah! Where are you [going]?” [And she said:] “We’re going to get sago starch.” [And I said:] “All right, go!”’

Knowledge Point: The word mïnja ‘speech’ often appears in clauses introducing \isi{reported speech}. Much like na ‘talk’, it may be used with an \isi{oblique marker} along with a verb of speaking. It may serve a discourse-\isi{deictic} function, pointing to what has just been reported or to what is about to be reported (i.e., ‘[someone] said this’), as in examples \REF{ex:syntax:225}, \REF{ex:syntax:226}, and \REF{ex:syntax:227}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï \textbf{mïnjan} \textbf{ndït} mambinalakan! | \gll nï \textbf{mïnja=n} ndï=\textbf{ta} ma-ambi=na-la-ka-n | \gls 1SG speech=OBL 3PL=say 3SG.OBJ-TOP=DETR-IRR-let-IMP | \glt `I told them: “Leave it alone!”’
Content 2: \gsrc Ndï \textbf{mïnjan ke}: Mï unanï wa mbïpe. | \gll ndï \textbf{mïnja=n} \textbf{kï}-e mï unan=nï wa mbï-p-e | \gls 3PL speech=OBL say-DEP 3SG.SUBJ 1PL.INCL=OBL village here-be{-ipfv} | \glt `They’re saying this: “It’s here in the village with us.”’
Content 3: \gsrc Thomas mï na nïte nï \textbf{mïnjan mat}: … | \gll Thomas mï na nï=ta-e nï \textbf{mïnja=n} ma=\textbf{ta} | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ talk 1SG=say-DEP 1SG speech=OBL 3SG.OBJ=say | \glt `When Thomas told me, I said to him: …’

Knowledge Point: Frequently, however, the word mïnja ‘speech’ occurs in a more \isi{elliptical} construction, in which it takes \isi{oblique} marking but where there is no expressed verb, as in \REF{ex:syntax:228} and \REF{ex:syntax:229}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nïnji inom mï \textbf{mïnjan} a nï inim lopop anmbï nay. | \gll nï-nji inom mï \textbf{mïnja=n} a nï inim lopo-p an-mbï na-i | \gls 1SG-POSS mother 3SG.SUBJ speech=OBL ah 1SG water wash-PFV out-here DETR-go.PFV | \glt `My mother said: “Ah! I bathed and came out.”’
Content 2: \gsrc Kowe Marungun min \textbf{mïnjan} a una yeta la unan ma maytana! | \gll Kowe Marungun min \textbf{mïnja=n} a unan yeta ala unan ma ma=ita-na | \gls [name] [name] 3DU speech=OBL ah 1PL.INCL man PL.DIST 1PL.INCL go 3SG.OBJ=build-IRR | \glt ‘Kowe and Marungun said: “Ah! We are men; let’s go and build it!”’
