Knowledge Point: Note the use of the \isi{interjection} a ‘ah!’ in \REF{ex:syntax:228} and \REF{ex:syntax:229}. Sometimes the word mïnja ‘speech’ stands alone, without any \isi{oblique} marking, to introduce \isi{reported speech}. In examples \REF{ex:syntax:230} and \REF{ex:syntax:231}, the \isi{interjection} m ‘hm!’ helps signal the start of quoted \isi{speech}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nïnji inom mï \textbf{mïnjan} a nï inim lopop anmbï nay. | \gll nï-nji inom mï \textbf{mïnja=n} a nï inim lopo-p an-mbï na-i | \gls 1SG-POSS mother 3SG.SUBJ speech=OBL ah 1SG water wash-PFV out-here DETR-go.PFV | \glt `My mother said: “Ah! I bathed and came out.”’
Content 2: \gsrc Kowe Marungun min \textbf{mïnjan} a una yeta la unan ma maytana! | \gll Kowe Marungun min \textbf{mïnja=n} a unan yeta ala unan ma ma=ita-na | \gls [name] [name] 3DU speech=OBL ah 1PL.INCL man PL.DIST 1PL.INCL go 3SG.OBJ=build-IRR | \glt ‘Kowe and Marungun said: “Ah! We are men; let’s go and build it!”’
Content 3: \gsrc Mï \textbf{mïnja m}! | \gll mï \textbf{mïnja} \textbf{m} | \gls 3SG.SUBJ speech hm | \glt `She said: “Hm!”’
Content 4: \gsrc An lïmndï ndala \textbf{mïnja m} ala ankam kuma lawo. | \gll an lïmndï ndï=ala \textbf{mïnja} \textbf{m} ala ankam kuma ala-awa=o | \gls 1PL.EXCL eye 3PL=see speech hm PL.DIST person some PL.DIST-INT=VOC | \glt `We saw them and said: “Hm! Those really are some different people!”’

Knowledge Point: When \isi{speech} is reported indirectly, two clauses are employed: a \isi{matrix clause} containing the verb of speaking and a \isi{dependent clause} containing the \isi{reported speech}. The \isi{dependent clause}, which consists of the indirect \isi{speech}, is embedded within the \isi{matrix clause}. Embedded \isi{dependent clause}s of \isi{indirect discourse} maintain Ulwa’s canonical S(O)V \isi{word order}. As in any clause, the subject of the \isi{embedded clause} may be omitted; this may be especially common when the subject of the \isi{embedded clause} matches that of the \isi{matrix clause} (e.g., ‘he\textsubscript{i} said that he\textsubscript{i} …’). In \REF{ex:syntax:232}, the form [na] (which is not necessarily required in such constructions) is analyzed as the \isi{detransitivizing} marker na- ‘\textsc{detr}’.
Content 1: \gsrc Alma mï Guren mï apa maytape \textbf{natap}. | \gll Alma mï {[Guren} mï apa {ma=ita-p-e]} na-\textbf{ta}-p | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ [[name] 3SG.SUBJ house 3SG.OBJ=build-PFV-DEP] DETR-say-PFV | \glt `Alma said that Guren built the house.’

Knowledge Point: The verb in the \isi{embedded clause} may be marked for \isi{irrealis} \isi{mood} if the reported statement refers to something that has not necessarily already transpired, as in \REF{ex:syntax:233} and \REF{ex:syntax:234}.
Content 1: \gsrc Mï mol \textbf{malanda} nate. | \gll mï [ma=ul ma=la-\textbf{nda}] na-ta-e | \gls 3SG.SUBJ [3SG.OBJ=with 3SG.OBJ=eat-IRR] DETR-say-DEP | \glt `She said that [she] would eat with him.’
Content 2: \gsrc Ndï i \textbf{mana} nakap. | \gll ndï i [ma-\textbf{na}] na-kï-p | \gls 3PL go.PFV [go-IRR] DETR-say-PFV | \glt `They came and talked about going.’

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{ex:syntax:235} suggests that it may also be possible for the \isi{embedded clause} of \isi{indirect discourse} to be embedded within a \isi{noun phrase} \isi{head}ed by the word na ‘talk’. In this analysis, the literal rendering of this sentence would be something like ‘yesterday, Dorothy told me would-sell-it talk’.
Content 1: \gsrc Dorothy awal makïke \textbf{lunda} na nïte. | \gll Dorothy awal [ma=kïke lo-\textbf{nda} na] nï=ta-e | \gls [name] yesterday [3SG.OBJ=throw go-IRR talk] 1SG=say-DEP | \glt `Yesterday, Dorothy told me that [she] would sell it.’

Knowledge Point: A \isi{reflexive} \isi{pronoun} may be used within the \isi{embedded clause} of \isi{speech} to refer to the speaker, which is the subject of the \isi{matrix clause}.\footnote{See examples \REF{ex:pron:23}, \REF{ex:pron:24}, and \REF{ex:pron:25} in \sectref{sec:6.3} for illustrations of how \isi{binding} principles apply within \isi{indirect discourse}.} This only seems to occur when the \isi{pronoun} referring to the speaker in the \isi{embedded clause} has a role other than subject; otherwise, no \isi{pronoun} is used at all. There is no designated \isi{logophoric pronoun} in Ulwa.
Content 1: \gsrc Wangasa Wore ngala ini tï \textbf{ambïnanda} nate. | \gll Wangasa\textsubscript{i} Wore ngala ini tï \textbf{ambï}\textsubscript{i}=na-nda na-ta-e | \gls [name] [place] PL.PROX ground take SG.REFL=give-IRR DETR-say-DEP | \glt `Wangasa says that these Wore [people] will give him land.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Ambïwalinda} \textbf{ambul} undate nakap. | \gll \textbf{ambï}=wali-nda \textbf{ambï}=ul unda-t-e na-kï-p | \gls SG.REFL=hit-IRR SG.REFL=with go{-spec-dep} DETR-say-PFV | \glt `[He] thought that [the crocodile] might go around with him to kill him.’
Content 3: \gsrc Kwa mï man \textbf{ambaweta} kap. | \gll kwa mï\textsubscript{i} ma=n \textbf{ambï}\textsubscript{i}=aweta kï-p | \gls one 3SG.SUBJ 3SG.OBJ=OBL SG.REFL=friend say-PFV | \glt `Someone said that it was his friend.’

Knowledge Point: Often a verb of speaking is used to refer to thinking (or other non-vocal events), as in examples \REF{ex:syntax:236}, \REF{ex:syntax:237}, and \REF{ex:syntax:238}. This use seems to be more common with the verb kï- ‘say’ than with the verb ta- ‘say’, with which it is otherwise mostly \isi{synonymous}. Note that there is no overt \isi{complementizer} used in complements of verbs of thinking.
Content 1: \gsrc Alma mï Guren mï apa mayte \textbf{nakap}. | \gll Alma mï {[Guren} mï apa {ma=ita-e]} na-\textbf{kï-p} | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ [[name] 3SG.SUBJ house 3SG.OBJ=build-DEP] DETR-say-PFV | \glt `Alma thought that Guren was building the house.’
Content 2: \gsrc Nï anmbï ina \textbf{nakap}. | \gll nï [an-mbï i-na] na-\textbf{kï-p} | \gls 1SG [out-here come-IRR] DETR-say-PFV | \glt `I thought about coming out here.’
Content 3: \gsrc Im maya ata mana \textbf{nakap}. | \gll {[im} ma=iya ata {ma-na]} na-\textbf{kï-p} | \gls {[tree} 3SG.OBJ=toward up go-IRR] DETR-say-PFV | \glt `[He] thought about going up a tree.’

Knowledge Point: In sentence \REF{ex:syntax:239}, the verb of speaking kï- ‘say’ is assisted by the form wana- ‘feel’, creating a \isi{compound} surrounding the \isi{embedded clause} of indirect \isi{speech} or thought, thus functioning as a \isi{discontinuous} \isi{compound verb} form (\sectref{sec:9.2.1}).
Content 1: \gsrc Nï \textbf{wana} ndï ndine lïpe ndï anmape \textbf{nakap}. | \gll nï \textbf{wana} {[ndï} ndï=in-e lï-p-e ndï {anma=p-e]} na-\textbf{kï-p} | \gls 1SG feel [3PL 3PL=get-DEP put-PFV-DEP 3PL good=COP{-dep]} DETR-say-PFV | \glt `I thought that they got them down and that they were good.’

Knowledge Point: A basic \isi{conditional} statement in Ulwa consists of two clauses, the first (the \isi{protasis}) expressing the condition, and the second (the \isi{apodosis}) expressing the consequence. There are variations to this pattern, though, such as sentences that include more than one \isi{protasis}, sentences that include more than one \isi{apodosis}, and sentences in which the result clause is not a statement, but rather a \isi{question} or a \isi{command}. An example of a simple \isi{conditional} sentence is given in \REF{ex:syntax:240}.
Content 1: \gsrc Inim \textbf{lopota} nï mana. | \gll inim lopo-\textbf{ta} nï ma-na | \gls water rain-COND 1SG go-IRR | \glt `If it rains, I’ll go.’

Knowledge Point: Conditional clauses in Ulwa can variously be translated in \ili{English} with ‘if’, ‘when’, ‘whenever’, ‘once’, ‘lest’, ‘even if’, or ‘even though’, depending on the context and intended meaning of the utterance. Sentences \REF{ex:syntax:241}, \REF{ex:syntax:242}, and \REF{ex:syntax:243} are all translated with ‘if’. The \isi{protasis} always precedes the \isi{apodosis} in an Ulwa \isi{conditional sentence}.
Content 1: \gsrc U atwana \textbf{nïkïta} nï utana. | \gll u atwana nï=kï-\textbf{ta} nï u=ta-na | \gls 2SG question 1SG=say{-cond} 1SG 2SG=say-IRR | \glt `If you ask me, I’ll tell you.’
Content 2: \gsrc Itom mï \textbf{mbita} unan landa. | \gll itom mï mbï-i-\textbf{ta} unan la-nda | \gls father 3SG.SUBJ here-go.PFV-COND 1PL.INCL eat-IRR | \glt `If father comes, we’ll eat.’
Content 3: \gsrc Mï \textbf{anmapïta} we ande ndï wolka mol nena. | \gll mï anma=p-\textbf{ta} we ande ndï wolka ma=ul na-i-na | \gls 3SG.SUBJ good=COP{-cond} then ok 3PL again 3SG.OBJ=with DETR-come-IRR | \glt `If he is well, then, OK, they would come back with him.’\footnote{This example also illustrates how \isi{conditional sentence}s may contain the \isi{subordinator} we ‘then’

Knowledge Point: The \isi{conditional sentence}s given in \REF{ex:syntax:244}, \REF{ex:syntax:245}, and \REF{ex:syntax:246} are better translated with ‘when’.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï anganika ma maya \textbf{mata} ngan lowonda. | \gll nï anganika ma ma=iya ma-\textbf{ta} ngan lo-wo-nda | \gls 1SG after go 3SG.OBJ=toward go-COND 1DU.EXCL IRR-sleep-IRR | \glt `When I later go, go to her, we two will sleep.’

Knowledge Point: As illustrated by \REF{ex:syntax:243}, the \isi{conditional} marker -ta ‘\textsc{cond}’ may follow the \isi{copular enclitic} =p ‘\textsc{cop}’ (\sectref{sec:10.2}). Sentence \REF{ex:syntax:247} also contains a \isi{copular enclitic}, as well as a \isi{periphrastic} ‘going’ verb in the \isi{apodosis} in lieu of a simple \isi{irrealis} verb.
Content 1: \gsrc Mï \textbf{anmapïta} we ande ndï wolka mol nena. | \gll mï anma=p-\textbf{ta} we ande ndï wolka ma=ul na-i-na | \gls 3SG.SUBJ good=COP{-cond} then ok 3PL again 3SG.OBJ=with DETR-come-IRR | \glt `If he is well, then, OK, they would come back with him.’\footnote{This example also illustrates how \isi{conditional sentence}s may contain the \isi{subordinator} we ‘then’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Tembipïta} ndï mo \textbf{ina mane}. | \gll tembi=p-\textbf{ta} ndï ma=u \textbf{i-na} \textbf{ma-n-e} | \gls bad=COP{-cond} 3PL 3SG.OBJ=from come-IRR go-IPFV-DEP | \glt `Whenever [people] were sick, they were going to come from there.’

Knowledge Point: The use of \isi{periphrastic} ‘going’ verbs in an \isi{apodosis} is further illustrated by sentence \REF{ex:syntax:248}, which also illustrates some of the complexity that is possible among \isi{conditional sentence}s in Ulwa. It is not uncommon for either the \isi{protasis} or the \isi{apodosis} (or both) to be multiclausal. Whereas the \isi{protasis} in \REF{ex:syntax:248} is \is{monoclausal construction} monoclausal (consisting of just a single verb, marked with the \isi{conditional} \isi{suffix} -ta ‘\textsc{cond}’), the \isi{apodosis} is multiclausal (consisting of first a perfective-marked verb and then a \isi{periphrastic} construction that gives the entire multiclausal \isi{apodosis} its \isi{irrealis} \isi{mood}).\footnote{Note that it is rare for the \isi{dependent-marker} \isi{suffix} to occur within \isi{conditional} clauses, even within multiclausal \is{apodosis} apodoses or \is{protasis} protases -- that is, it does not occur anywhere except at the very end of the \isi{apodosis}, as in \REF{ex:syntax:248}. These clauses are thus considered to be \isi{coordinate} structures (\sectref{sec:12.1}). The perfective-marked verb in this example can thus be considered an \isi{irrealis perfective} (\sectref{sec:4.9}); and the \isi{periphrastic} construction (technically an \isi{irrealis}-marked verb plus an imperfective-marked verb) can thus be considered the requisite \isi{irrealis} construction of the \isi{apodosis}.}

Knowledge Point: Like example \REF{ex:syntax:248}, example \REF{ex:syntax:249} illustrates an \isi{irrealis perfective} in the \isi{apodosis}, here \isi{morphological}ly clearer since the form of the verb is lamap {‘eat} \linebreak {[\textsc{irr/pfv}]’} (cf. \sectref{sec:4.9}).
Content 1: \gsrc Nduwe unïn anmbïlumopta un nul ndinap \textbf{ndulunda mane}. | \gll ndï=we un=ïn an-mbï-lumo-p-ta un nï=ul ndï=ina-p \textbf{ndï=u-lo-nda} \textbf{ma-n-e} | \gls 3PL=cut 2PL=OBL out-here-put-PFV-COND 2PL 1SG=with 3PL=get-PFV 3PL=from-cut-IRR go-IPFV-DEP | \glt `Once [I] have cut them [= tobacco leaves] out for you, you, having gotten them with me, are going to peel them.’
Content 2: \gsrc U mat ita nï \textbf{malamap} wa \textbf{mana}. | \gll u ma=tï i-ta nï \textbf{ma=la-ama-p} wa \textbf{ma-na} | \gls 2SG 3SG.OBJ=take go.PFV-COND 1SG 3SG.OBJ=IRR-eat-PFV village go-IRR | \glt `If you bring it, I’ll eat it and go home.’

Knowledge Point: In addition to exhibiting a multiclausal \isi{apodosis}, sentence \REF{ex:syntax:249} exemplifies a \isi{protasis} that contains two verbs. The first verb tï- ‘take’, however, is often \isi{defective} and \isi{semantic}ally closely connected to the following verb (often ma- {\textasciitilde} i- ‘go’ or na- ‘give’), so this is perhaps not the clearest example of multiple clauses. In the \isi{conditional sentence}s given in \REF{ex:syntax:250} and \REF{ex:syntax:251}, the verb tï- ‘take’ is used both in the \isi{protasis} and in the \isi{apodosis}.
Content 1: \gsrc U mat ita nï \textbf{malamap} wa \textbf{mana}. | \gll u ma=tï i-ta nï \textbf{ma=la-ama-p} wa \textbf{ma-na} | \gls 2SG 3SG.OBJ=take go.PFV-COND 1SG 3SG.OBJ=IRR-eat-PFV village go-IRR | \glt `If you bring it, I’ll eat it and go home.’

Knowledge Point: In sentence \REF{ex:syntax:252}, the verb tï- ‘take’ is indeed marked for \isi{TAM} (here, \isi{perfective}).
Content 1: \gsrc Kalam \textbf{ngatïn} mol luta ngaya ndapïna. | \gll kalam nga=\textbf{tï-n} ma=ul lo-ta ngaya anda=p-na | \gls knowledge SG.PROX=take-PFV 3SG.OBJ=with go-COND far SG.DIST=be-IRR | \glt `If he gets this knowledge and goes around with it, he will be far away.’

Knowledge Point: Notably, there is no \isi{conditional} marking on the first verb in the \isi{protasis}, even though it is not \isi{defective} here. There are, however, instances in which multiple verbs in the \isi{protasis} may be marked with the \isi{conditional} \isi{suffix} -ta ‘\textsc{cond}’. In such sentences, it can be assumed that each verb represents a condition that must be met for the state or event in the \isi{apodosis} to be or occur. Often these are best translated in \ili{English} with a single clause, often with a single verb. The Ulwa sentence, however, contains multiple verbs in the \isi{protasis} that may constitute either a single clause with multiple \isi{verb phrase}s or a multiclausal \isi{protasis}, as in \REF{ex:syntax:253}.\footnote{This sentence has two verbs marked with the \isi{conditional} \isi{suffix} -ta ‘\textsc{cond}’ in the \isi{protasis} (literally ‘if you are just here and if [you] eat food …’). Note that a simple \isi{irrealis} \isi{stem} of ama- ‘eat’ (i.e., [la-]) is employed, and not an \isi{irrealis perfective} \isi{compound} \isi{stem} (i.e., not \textsuperscript{†}/la-ama-/). This is because the \isi{hypothetical} event in the \isi{protasis} is not \isi{perfective} – that is, the event need not have been completed for the situation in the \isi{apodosis} to be true.}
Content 1: \gsrc U kwa \textbf{mapta} mundu \textbf{lata} tamndï ko mundu ndïwalin. | \gll u kwa ma=p-\textbf{ta} mundu la-\textbf{ta} tamndï ko mundu ndï=wali-n[da] | \gls 2SG just 3SG.OBJ=be{-cond} food eat{-cond} owner just hunger 3PL=hit-IRR | \glt `If you just eat the food there, the owners will go hungry.’

Knowledge Point: Note, however, that verbs in the \isi{protasis} clause or clauses should properly be marked as \isi{conditional} only if the \isi{apodosis} is in fact contingent on them. Thus, in sentence \REF{ex:syntax:254}, the first verb (in fact a \isi{verbalized} noun) receives no \isi{conditional} \isi{suffix}, but rather is \isi{dependent-marked}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Nungolkepe} nï mandïm sata mï nït awi lïp nul wandam mana. | \gll nungolke=p-\textbf{e} nï ma=andïm sa-ta mï nï=tï awi lï-p nï=ul wandam ma-na | \gls child=COP{-dep} 1SG 3SG.OBJ=for cry{-cond} 3SG.SUBJ 1SG=take shoulder put-PFV 1SG=with jungle go-IRR | \glt `When [I] was a child and I would cry for him [= my father], he would put me on his shoulder and go with me to the jungle.’

Knowledge Point: The \isi{protasis} may have any number of \isi{conditional}ly marked verbs, however. Sentence \REF{ex:syntax:255} contains three.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Mambilakata} \textbf{mankïta} keka itïm \textbf{nomopta} una wo lolop wa pïn. | \gll ma-ambi=la-ka-\textbf{ta} ma=nïkï-\textbf{ta} keka itïm na-lumo-p-\textbf{ta} unan wa lolop wa p-na | \gls 3SG.OBJ-TOP=IRR-let-COND 3SG.OBJ=dig-COND completely trash DETR-put-PFV-COND 1PL.INCL just just village be-IRR | \glt `If [we] abandon it, cut it [out], and throw [it] completely in the trash, [then] we will just stay [fine here] in the village.’

Knowledge Point: It is also possible for the \isi{conditional} \isi{suffix} to appear on one or more verbs in the \isi{apodosis}. I suspect that this is a form of overextension, marking a clause as \isi{conditional} simply because it is connected to a \isi{conditional} clause. This may be seen in examples \REF{ex:syntax:256} and \REF{ex:syntax:257}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Nditapta} kalam mï \textbf{natïnangata}. | \gll ndï=ita-p-\textbf{ta} kalam mï na-tïnanga-\textbf{ta} | \gls 3PL=build-PFV-COND knowledge 3SG.SUBJ DETR-arise-COND | \glt `When [they] build them [= school buildings], knowledge will increase.’
Content 2: \gsrc U mat nonal luwa \textbf{malta} mï lowop \textbf{tembipïta}. | \gll u ma=tï nonal luwa ma=lï-\textbf{ta} mï lo-wo-p tembi=p-\textbf{ta} | \gls 2SG 3SG.OBJ=take wind place 3SG.OBJ=put-IRR-COND 3SG.SUBJ IRR-sleep-IRR bad=COP{-cond} | \glt `If you put it out in the open air, it will go bad overnight.’

Knowledge Point: Since clauses in the \isi{apodosis} may also be marked with the \isi{conditional} \isi{suffix} -ta ‘\textsc{cond}’, it is sometimes not entirely clear whether a clause belongs to the \isi{protasis} or to the \isi{apodosis} – that is, in instances in which a \isi{conditional} sentence contains more than two clauses. Sentence \REF{ex:syntax:258} illustrates this possible ambiguity.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: While many \isi{conditional sentence}s have statements as \is{apodosis} apodoses, it is also possible for a \isi{conditional sentence} to have a \isi{question} or a \isi{command} as the \isi{apodosis}. In example \REF{ex:syntax:259}, the \isi{apodosis} takes the form of a \isi{question}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï \textbf{mamata} olsem ko kwa \textbf{mbïpïta} lïmndï \textbf{ndutata} ay \textbf{nïkïta} ndul landa? | \gll nï ma=ma-\textbf{ta} olsem ko kwa mbï-p-\textbf{ta} lïmndï ndï=uta-\textbf{ta} ay nïkï-\textbf{ta} ndï=ul la-nda | \gls 1SG 3SG.OBJ=go-COND thus just one here-be{-cond} eye 3PL=grind{-cond} sago dig-COND 3PL=with eat-IRR | \glt `If I were to go there, who would stay here, watch after them, prepare sago, and eat with them?’

Knowledge Point: Note the extensive use of \isi{conditional}-marked verbs throughout example \REF{ex:syntax:259}; indeed, every verb except the final \isi{irrealis} verb in the \isi{apodosis} exhibits the \isi{conditional} \isi{suffix} -ta ‘\textsc{cond}’. Example \REF{ex:syntax:260} also has a \isi{question} for its \isi{apodosis}. Here, only one verb is marked with the \isi{suffix} -ta ‘\textsc{cond}’.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï \textbf{mamata} olsem ko kwa \textbf{mbïpïta} lïmndï \textbf{ndutata} ay \textbf{nïkïta} ndul landa? | \gll nï ma=ma-\textbf{ta} olsem ko kwa mbï-p-\textbf{ta} lïmndï ndï=uta-\textbf{ta} ay nïkï-\textbf{ta} ndï=ul la-nda | \gls 1SG 3SG.OBJ=go-COND thus just one here-be{-cond} eye 3PL=grind{-cond} sago dig-COND 3PL=with eat-IRR | \glt `If I were to go there, who would stay here, watch after them, prepare sago, and eat with them?’
Content 2: \gsrc Un nambï \textbf{kenmbupïta} un anjikaka imbamka lunda? | \gll un nambï kenmbu=p-\textbf{ta} un anjikaka imbam-ka lo-nda | \gls 2PL skin heavy=COP{-cond} 2PL how run-let go-IRR | \glt `But if your body is heavy, how can you run around?’

Knowledge Point: It is possible for the \isi{question} word to occur in the \isi{protasis} even when (at least in the \ili{English} translation) the \isi{interrogative} would be expected to occur in the \isi{apodosis}, as is the case in \REF{ex:syntax:261}. This may have something to do with the placement and \isi{scope} of the \isi{negator} ango ‘\textsc{neg}’ in \isi{multiclausal construction}s (\sectref{sec:13.3.3}), since the \isi{question word}s are etymologically related to ango ‘\textsc{neg}’.
Content 1: \gsrc Una \textbf{ango} luwa pïta inim malanda? | \gll unan \textbf{ango} luwa p-ta inim ma=la-nda | \gls 1PL.INCL NEG place be{-cond} water 3SG.OBJ=eat-IRR | \glt `Where will we drink water?’

Knowledge Point: It is also common for \is{apodosis} apodoses to take the form of \isi{imperative}s. In fact, \isi{conditional} constructions often serve the \isi{pragmatic} function of softening a \isi{request} or \isi{command} (\sectref{sec:13.2}), as seen in \REF{ex:syntax:262}.
Content 1: \gsrc Un ma ya koya ata ma \textbf{maynapta} nditap ndïtïl nap ndït \textbf{ita} una \textbf{ndutata} inim uta ndïlan! | \gll un ma ya ko=iya ata ma ma=ina-p-\textbf{ta} ndï=ita-p ndï=tïl na-p ndï=tï i-\textbf{ta} unan ndï=uta-\textbf{ta} inim u-ta ndï=la-n | \gls 2PL go coconut INDF=toward up go 3SG.OBJ=get-PFV-COND 3PL=build-PFV 3PL=husk DETR-be 3PL=take go.PFV-COND 1PL.INCL 3PL=grind{-cond} water put{-cond} 3PL=eat-IMP | \glt `If you go, go up a coconut tree, and get it, [and] if [you] tie them [= the coconuts], husk them, and bring them, [then] we will grind them into water and eat them!’

Knowledge Point: Although presented as a series of conditions, the first clauses in sentence \REF{ex:syntax:262} are \isi{pragmatic}ally tantamount to a \isi{request} (i.e., ‘please get coconuts so that we may grind them and eat them’). Note also how the \isi{conditional} form -ta ‘\textsc{cond}’ occurs in (what is translated here as) the \isi{apodosis}. Another example of a \isi{conditional} form used in a \isi{command} is given in \REF{ex:syntax:263}.
Content 1: \gsrc Un ma ya koya ata ma \textbf{maynapta} nditap ndïtïl nap ndït \textbf{ita} una \textbf{ndutata} inim uta ndïlan! | \gll un ma ya ko=iya ata ma ma=ina-p-\textbf{ta} ndï=ita-p ndï=tïl na-p ndï=tï i-\textbf{ta} unan ndï=uta-\textbf{ta} inim u-ta ndï=la-n | \gls 2PL go coconut INDF=toward up go 3SG.OBJ=get-PFV-COND 3PL=build-PFV 3PL=husk DETR-be 3PL=take go.PFV-COND 1PL.INCL 3PL=grind{-cond} water put{-cond} 3PL=eat-IMP | \glt `If you go, go up a coconut tree, and get it, [and] if [you] tie them [= the coconuts], husk them, and bring them, [then] we will grind them into water and eat them!’

Knowledge Point: Finally, in \isi{prohibition}s, the \isi{conditional} \isi{suffix} -ta ‘\textsc{cond}’ may be employed without any following \isi{apodosis}, as in \REF{ex:syntax:265}. This may be considered a form of \isi{ellipsis}. Alternatively, it could be the case that the \isi{suffix} here is related to the \isi{speculative} \isi{suffix} -t ‘\textsc{spec}’ (\sectref{sec:4.11}), which is also often used in \isi{negative command}s.

Knowledge Point: Counterfactual sentences in Ulwa generally employ a verb with \isi{irrealis} marking, as illustrated by \REF{ex:syntax:266}.
Content 1: \gsrc Apïn kali \textbf{malnda} inim ngalope nï makam. | \gll apïn kali ma=lï\textbf{-nda} inim nga=lo-p-e nï ma=kamb | \gls fire send 3SG.OBJ=put-IRR water SG.PROX=cut-PFV-DEP 1SG 3SG.OBJ=shun | \glt `[I] would have burned it, but this rain came, so I didn’t want to.’

Knowledge Point: The \isi{irrealis} \isi{mood} is a natural resource for designating \isi{counterfactual} statements. While one prolific use of the \isi{irrealis} \isi{mood} is to mark \isi{future} states or events, which are in a sense always \isi{counterfactual}, the \isi{irrealis} \isi{mood} can also be applied to \isi{hypothetical} states or events in \isi{present} or \isi{past} \isi{time} that are known not to be true. Sentence \REF{ex:syntax:267} posits a \isi{hypothetical} event in the \isi{past} that is known not to have occurred. In this sentence, an \isi{irrealis} form is used. This may be contrasted with the \isi{perfective} forms used in the second clause to mark what was known to have occurred.
Content 1: \gsrc Wa \textbf{mbïpïna} Kowe awa mangusuwa asape mï i. | \gll wa mbï-p-\textbf{na} Kowe awa ma-ngusuwa asa-p-e mï i | \gls village here-be-IRR [name] INT 3SG.OBJ-poor hit-PFV-DEP 3SG.SUBJ go.PFV | \glt ‘[Kïtalwe] would have stayed in the village, but Kowe himself hit the poor thing [= Kïtalwe] and he [= Kïtalwe] left.’

Knowledge Point: Counterfactual statements are frequently used in \isi{conditional sentence}s, presenting \isi{hypothetical} states or events, whether in the \isi{past} or in the \isi{present}. Examples \REF{ex:syntax:268} and \REF{ex:syntax:269} illustrate \isi{counterfactual} \isi{conditional} statements referring to \isi{past} \isi{time}.
