Knowledge Point: \is{active voice} Active sentences in Ulwa have a fairly rigid SOV \isi{constituent order} (\sectref{sec:11.1}), as in \REF{ex:syntax:272}. In \isi{passive} sentences, on the other hand, the verb occupies a different position: it precedes the subject, as in \REF{ex:syntax:273}.
Content 1: \gsrc Yeta mï lamndu \textbf{masap}. | \gll yeta mï lamndu \textbf{ma=asa-p} | \gls man 3SG.SUBJ pig 3SG.OBJ=hit-PFV | \glt `The man killed the pig.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Asape} lamndu mï. | \gll \textbf{asa-p-e} lamndu mï | \gls hit-PFV-DEP pig 3SG.SUBJ | \glt `The pig was killed.’

Knowledge Point: Likewise, in the \isi{active-voice} sentence in \REF{ex:syntax:274}, the \isi{word order} is SOV, whereas in the passive-\isi{voice} sentence in \REF{ex:syntax:275}, the \isi{word order} is VS. The subject argument in the \isi{passive} sentence corresponds to the object argument of its \is{active voice} active equivalent.
Content 1: \gsrc Inom utam \textbf{nduwanap}. | \gll inom utam \textbf{ndï=wana-p} | \gls mother yam 3PL=cook-PFV | \glt `Mother cooked the yams.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Wanape} utam ndï. | \gll \textbf{wana-p-e} utam ndï | \gls cook-PFV-DEP yam 3PL | \glt `The yams were cooked.’

Knowledge Point: As the grammatical subject in the \isi{passive} sentence, the postverbal \isi{patient}-like argument is the only obligatory argument of the verb. As the subject, it is marked not with the \isi{object marker} but with the \isi{subject marker}.\footnote{Although these markers are usually \isi{homophonous}, there is a distinction in the 3\textsc{sg} form: mï ‘3\textsc{sg.subj’} for subjects and ma= ‘3\textsc{sg.obj’} for \isi{non-subject}s (\sectref{sec:7.2}, \sectref{sec:11.2}). Crucially, as in example \REF{ex:syntax:273}, the form [mï] (and not \textsuperscript{†}[ma]) follows the subject of the \isi{passive} clause.} Furthermore, the verb in the \isi{passive} sentence does not permit an \isi{object-marker} \isi{proclitic}, since the \isi{semantic} \isi{patient} (the object of the equivalent \is{active voice} active sentence) has been promoted to the role of subject. The difference in \isi{word order} between \isi{active-voice} and \isi{passive-voice} clauses is presented in \REF{ex:syntax:275a}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Asape} lamndu mï. | \gll \textbf{asa-p-e} lamndu mï | \gls hit-PFV-DEP pig 3SG.SUBJ | \glt `The pig was killed.’
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: The verb in the \isi{passive} clause generally requires the \isi{suffix} -e ‘\textsc{dep}’.\footnote{The form [-e] serves several functions in Ulwa. Although it is glossed here as ‘\textsc{dep}’ (i.e., “\isi{dependent}”), these \isi{passive} sentences are analyzed as being \isi{independent}, since they serve as complete sentences, without needing any additional clause, stated or implied.} Although not functioning synchronically as \isi{dependent clause}s, these \isi{passive} sentences may have developed diachronically from a type of \isi{dependent clause}, namely, \isi{relative clause}s. Since \isi{relative clause}s in Ulwa employ a \is{gap strategy} gapping strategy, they leave themselves open to \isi{reanalysis} as \isi{head-internal relative clause}s with \isi{inverted word order} (\sectref{sec:12.3}). For example, a set of \isi{matrix clause} and \isi{relative clause} as in \REF{ex:syntax:276} (with the subject “gapped”) could be \isi{reanalyzed} as the structure presented in \REF{ex:syntax:277} (with \isi{inverted word order}).
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: Perhaps examples such as \REF{ex:syntax:273} and \REF{ex:syntax:275} could be analyzed as \isi{relative clause}s. For example, sentence \REF{ex:syntax:275} could actually mean something like ‘the yams that were cooked’. However, since these examples are all fully capable of serving as \isi{independent} sentences, not \isi{dependent} on any other clause, they are analyzed here as indeed \isi{passive} sentences and not as \isi{relative clause}s.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Asape} lamndu mï. | \gll \textbf{asa-p-e} lamndu mï | \gls hit-PFV-DEP pig 3SG.SUBJ | \glt `The pig was killed.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Wanape} utam ndï. | \gll \textbf{wana-p-e} utam ndï | \gls cook-PFV-DEP yam 3PL | \glt `The yams were cooked.’
Content 3: \gsrc \textbf{Wanape} utam ndï. | \gll \textbf{wana-p-e} utam ndï | \gls cook-PFV-DEP yam 3PL | \glt `The yams were cooked.’

Knowledge Point: The \isi{suffix} \textit{{}-e} ‘\textsc{dep}’ does not appear, at least not overtly, in \isi{irrealis}-\isi{mood} passives. Since the \isi{irrealis} \isi{suffix} invariably ends in [-a], and a \isi{phonological} rule would syncopate a following /e/, it is, however, possible that there is an underlying \isi{suffix} /-e/ even in these \isi{irrealis}-\isi{mood} passives. Sentence \REF{ex:syntax:278} provides an example of an \isi{irrealis}-\isi{mood} \isi{passive} sentence.
Content 1: \gsrc Umbe \textbf{walinda} lamndu. | \gll umbe wali-\textbf{nda} lamndu | \gls tomorrow hit-IRR pig | \glt `The pig will be killed tomorrow.’

Knowledge Point: When \isi{passive} clauses contain \isi{discontinuous} verb forms (\sectref{sec:9.2.1}), the entire verbal unit occurs prenominally, as in \REF{ex:syntax:279}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Lïmndï ale} ankam. | \gll \textbf{lïmndï} \textbf{ala-e} ankam | \gls eye see-DEP person | \glt `The man was seen.’

Knowledge Point: Sentences \REF{ex:syntax:280} and \REF{ex:syntax:281}, which are examples of simple \isi{passive} sentences taken from texts, reveal some of the \isi{pragmatic} functions of \isi{passive} sentences. In sentence \REF{ex:syntax:280}, the speaker is introducing a new topic and placing emphasis on the action (the killing of pigs) and not on the \isi{agent}s of this action. In sentence \REF{ex:syntax:281}, the role of the \isi{agent} (the people who eat food in the dry season) is negligible; rather, the important point is -- quite impersonally -- that the dry season is a time when there is plenty food.
Content 1: \gsrc Asape nungol! | \gll asa-p-e nungol | \gls hit-PFV-DEP child | \glt `Piglets were killed!’
Content 2: \gsrc Ane se ame mundu. | \gll ane sa-e ama-e mundu | \gls sun cry-DEP eat-DEP food | \glt `When the sun is shining, food is eaten.’
Content 3: \gsrc Asape nungol! | \gll asa-p-e nungol | \gls hit-PFV-DEP child | \glt `Piglets were killed!’
Content 4: \gsrc Ane se ame mundu. | \gll ane sa-e ama-e mundu | \gls sun cry-DEP eat-DEP food | \glt `When the sun is shining, food is eaten.’

Knowledge Point: Although the \isi{agent} of a \isi{passive} sentence need not be expressed, it can be included as an \isi{oblique} \isi{phrase}. In \is{active voice} active sentences, \isi{oblique}s (such as \isi{temporal adverb}s) occur either in clause-initial position or immediately before the \isi{verb phrase} -- that is, before the verb in \isi{intransitive} clauses, and before the object of the verb in \isi{transitive} clauses. Likewise, the \isi{agent} \isi{oblique} \isi{phrase}, if included, appears at the beginning of the \isi{passive} clause, immediately before the verb. The \isi{oblique marker} =n ‘\textsc{obl}’ (\sectref{sec:11.4.1}) is used to identify the \isi{agent} of \isi{passive} verbs, as in sentences \REF{ex:syntax:282}, \REF{ex:syntax:283}, and \REF{ex:syntax:284}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Ankamnï} toplïpe mana. | \gll \textbf{ankam=nï} top-lï-p-e mana | \gls person=OBL throw-put-PFV-DEP spear | \glt `The spear was thrown by the man.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Ndïn} asape lamndu. | \gll \textbf{ndï=n} asa-p-e lamndu | \gls 3PL=OBL hit-PFV-DEP pig | \glt `The pig was killed by them.’
Content 3: \gsrc \textbf{Nungolnï} lukawtim mape nga. | \gll \textbf{nungol=nï} lukawtim ma=p-e nga | \gls child=OBL look.after 3SG.OBJ=be{-dep} SG.PROX | \glt `This one was looked after by [my] son.’

Knowledge Point: It should be noted that \isi{passive} sentences are very rare in Ulwa discourse. I suspect that they are being lost as the language experiences \isi{grammatical attrition} in the face of \isi{obsolescence} (see \chapref{sec:15}). In many situations in which one might expect to find a \isi{passive} construction (i.e., situations in which the role of the \isi{agent} of a \isi{transitive} sentence is to be downplayed), alternative structures are often used. For example, some speakers use \isi{impersonal construction}s. Since a pronominal subject can be omitted, it is possible to say something along the lines of ‘[they] did something’, in which the non-specific subject ‘they’ is unstated altogether, as in \REF{ex:syntax:285} and \REF{ex:syntax:286}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nip malpe. | \gll ni-p ma=lï-p-e | \gls die-PFV 3SG.OBJ=put-PFV-DEP | \glt `[He] died and [they] buried him.’
Content 2: \gsrc Lungum anda matï Tapon nana. | \gll lungum anda ma=tï Tapon na-na | \gls long.spear SG.DIST 3SG.OBJ=take [name] give-PFV | \glt `[They] gave a long spear to Tapon.’

Knowledge Point: Passivization, however, which can promote a \isi{direct object} to subject, provides a means for conveying the meaning of a sentence like ‘Ginam saw the pig that the man killed’, changing the sentence, as it were, to a sentence like ‘Ginam saw the pig that was killed by the man.’ The sentence in Ulwa would appear as in \REF{ex:syntax:287}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ginam lïmndï ankamnï asape lamndu mala. | \gll Ginam lïmndï [ankam=nï asa-p-e] lamndu ma=ala | \gls [name] eye [person=OBL hit-PFV-DEP] pig 3SG.OBJ=see | \glt `Ginam saw the pig that the man killed.’

Knowledge Point: It is a rather straightforward process to have the \isi{head noun} in an \isi{independent clause}, such as lam ‘meat’ in \REF{ex:syntax:288} or \REF{ex:syntax:289}, function as the subject of a \isi{relative clause}, as in \REF{ex:syntax:290}.
Content 1: \gsrc Inom mï \textbf{lam} mawanap. | \gll inom mï \textbf{lam} ma=wana-p | \gls mother 3SG.SUBJ meat 3SG.OBJ=cook-PFV | \glt `Mother cooked the meat.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Lam} mï nungol masap. | \gll \textbf{lam} mï nungol ma=asa-p | \gls meat 3SG.SUBJ child 3SG.OBJ=hit-PFV | \glt `The meat killed the child.’
Content 3: \gsrc Inom mï nungol masape \textbf{lam} mawanap. | \gll inom mï [nungol ma=asa-p-e] \textbf{lam} ma=wana-p | \gls mother 3SG.SUBJ [child 3SG.OBJ=hit-PFV-DEP] meat 3SG.OBJ=cook-PFV | \glt `Mother cooked the meat that killed the child.’

Knowledge Point: It is not, however, possible, for the \isi{head noun} in the \isi{matrix clause} to correspond to a \isi{direct object} in the \isi{relative clause}. Thus, lam ‘meat’ in \REF{ex:syntax:291} cannot be \isi{relativize}d. However, a comparable meaning can be conveyed by using a \isi{passive} construction in the \isi{relative clause}, as in \REF{ex:syntax:292}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nungol mï \textbf{lam} mamap. | \gll nungol mï \textbf{lam} ma=ama-p | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ meat 3SG.OBJ=eat-PFV | \glt `The child ate the meat.’
Content 2: \gsrc Inom mï nungolnï amape \textbf{lam} mawanap. | \gll inom mï [nungol=nï ama-p-e] \textbf{lam} ma=wana-p | \gls mother 3SG.SUBJ [child=OBL eat-PFV-DEP] meat 3SG.OBJ=cook-PFV | \glt `Mother cooked the meat that the child ate.’

Knowledge Point: It is perhaps due to this usefulness that the \isi{passive} \isi{voice} does still appear in discourse, often in other complex constructions that employ \isi{relative clause}s, like in \REF{ex:syntax:293}.
Content 1: \gsrc U ko nananï nïwat lape mïnda ngawonp. | \gll u ko nana=nï nï=wat la-p-e mïnda nga=won-p-e | \gls 2SG just mama=OBL 1SG=atop plant-PFV-DEP banana SG.PROX=cut-PFV-DEP | \glt `You just cut this banana tree that was planted above me by mama.’

Knowledge Point: In considering \isi{A-lability}, we may note that it seems that essentially any verb in Ulwa may occur without an expressed object. Although this could be taken to suggest that there exist no truly \isi{transitive} verbs in Ulwa, an alternative view would be that at least some instances in which a putatively \isi{ambitransitive} verb occurs without an overtly expressed object are examples of \is{object deletion} \isi{indefinite object deletion} (\citealt[124--125]{Næss2007}). For example, the verb ama- ‘eat’ may occur either with \REF{ex:syntax:294} or without \REF{ex:syntax:295} an expressed object; when no object is stated, however, it could be argued that there is an \isi{indefinite} object (i.e., ‘food’) that has simply been deleted.\footnote{Crosslinguistically, the verb ‘eat’ often behaves idiosyncratically in terms of \isi{transitivity} \citep{Næss2009}. Thus, it should perhaps not be taken as indicating too much about \isi{transitivity} in the language in general. Nevertheless, Ulwa may here be contrasted with other \ili{Keram} languages, such as \ili{Mwakai} and \ili{Ap Ma}, in which the \isi{semantic}ally light noun si ‘things’ (in both languages) is commonly used as the object of the verb ‘eat’ when no particular food is being specified. Thus, in contrast to its sister languages, Ulwa -- or at least the \ili{Manu} \isi{dialect} of Ulwa -- seems to have an \isi{ambitransitive} verb meaning ‘eat’. In the \ili{Maruat-Dimiri-Yaul} \isi{dialect}, on the other hand, ‘eat’ generally takes the object mundï ‘food’, when no particular food is being specified. Although contrasts such as the one exemplified by \REF{ex:syntax:294} and \REF{ex:syntax:295} suggest the possible \isi{ambitransitivity} (namely, \isi{A-lability}) of the verb ‘eat’, it is common in the \ili{Manu} \isi{dialect} for the \isi{detransitivizing} \isi{prefix} na- \textsc{‘detr’} to occur with ‘eat’ when no particular food is being specified (\sectref{sec:13.8.2}).}
Content 1: \gsrc Nï ta lamndu amap. | \gll nï ta lamndu ama-p | \gls 1SG already pig eat-PFV | \glt `I have already eaten pork.’
Content 2: \gsrc Nï ta amap. | \gll nï ta ama-p | \gls 1SG already eat-PFV | \glt `I have already eaten.’
Content 3: \gsrc Nï ta lamndu amap. | \gll nï ta lamndu ama-p | \gls 1SG already pig eat-PFV | \glt `I have already eaten pork.’
Content 4: \gsrc Nï ta amap. | \gll nï ta ama-p | \gls 1SG already eat-PFV | \glt `I have already eaten.’

Knowledge Point: Next, we may consider \isi{P-lability}. Ulwa does not have a class of \isi{patient}-\linebreak preserving \is{lability} labile verbs. Verbal notions such as ‘break’ and ‘burn’, which are crosslinguistically more likely to be expressed with P-labile verbs, occur in Ulwa as pairs of unrelated verbs (i.e., ‘break [\isi{transitive}]’ vs. ‘break [\isi{intransitive}]’ and ‘burn [\isi{transitive}]’ vs. ‘burn [\isi{intransitive}]’). In the terms of \citet{NicholsEtAl2004}, Ulwa could be said to have an \is{indeterminate valence orientation} “indeterminate” \isi{valence orientation}, since the correspondences between “plain” and “induced” verbs are generally of the \isi{suppletive} variety \REF{ex:syntax:295a}.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: There are, for example, several ways of encoding ‘breaking’ events in Ulwa, but none of them instantiates \isi{P-lability}. The verbs a- ‘break’, kol- ‘break, split’, kot- ‘break, bear’, and kun- ‘break, break off’ are all \isi{transitive}, with the P argument referring to that which is broken; the verbs nungun u- ‘break (\isi{intransitive})’ and tukul- ‘break (\isi{intransitive})’, on the other hand, are both \isi{intransitive}, with the S argument referring to that which is broken. Sentence \REF{ex:syntax:296} exemplifies the use of the \isi{intransitive} verb tukul- ‘break’.
Content 1: \gsrc Amun nïnji maka palapal min mï maka \textbf{tukulp}. | \gll amun nï-nji maka palapal min mï maka \textbf{tukul}-p | \gls now 1SG-POSS thus decoration? band 3SG.SUBJ thus break-PFV | \glt `Now, my, like, shell armband has broken like this.’

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{ex:syntax:296} may be compared with example \REF{ex:otherwc:105} in \sectref{sec:8.2.3}, which illustrates the use of the \isi{intransitive} verb nungun u- ‘break’.
Content 1: \gsrc Amun nïnji maka palapal min mï maka \textbf{tukulp}. | \gll amun nï-nji maka palapal min mï maka \textbf{tukul}-p | \gls now 1SG-POSS thus decoration? band 3SG.SUBJ thus break-PFV | \glt `Now, my, like, shell armband has broken like this.’
Content 2: \gsrc Mï \textbf{keka} nungunup. | \gll mï \textbf{keka} nungun-u-p | \gls 3SG.SUBJ completely break-put-PFV | \glt `It broke completely.’

Knowledge Point: Although tukul- ‘break’ may be etymologically related to kol- ‘break’, kot- ‘break’, or kun- ‘break’, it is not synchronically derived by any process (i.e., there is no known \isi{prefix} \textsuperscript{†}/tu-/). At any rate, the \isi{transitive} verb a- ‘break’ is not related to any of these forms, whether diachronically or synchronically. An example of this \isi{transitive} verb is given in \REF{ex:syntax:297}, which may be compared with example \REF{ex:det:133} in \sectref{sec:7.3} and example \REF{ex:det:199} in \sectref{sec:7.5}, which contain similar uses of this verb.
Content 1: \gsrc May mïnkïn \textbf{map} | \gll ma=i mïnkïn ma=\textbf{a}-p | \gls 3SG.OBJ=go.PFV sago.species 3SG.OBJ=break-PFV | \glt `[We] went there and broke a sago palm.’
Content 2: \gsrc Mï ya uta \textbf{nginanda}. | \gll mï ya uta \textbf{ngin}=a-nda | \gls 3SG.SUBJ coconut shell DU.PROX=break-IRR | \glt `He will break these two coconut shells.’
Content 3: \gsrc \textbf{Un kuma} anangani pe imot aye. | \gll \textbf{un} \textbf{kuma} an=angani p-e imot a-e | \gls 2PL some 1PL.EXCL=behind be{-dep} log break-IPFV | \glt `Some of you are behind us, breaking firewood.’

Knowledge Point: Like ‘break’, the verbal notion of ‘burn’ in Ulwa is encoded with different verbs for \isi{transitive} and \isi{intransitive} meanings. The \isi{intransitive} verb is wo- ‘burn, blaze’, which does not take an object. \isi{Transitive} constructions, on the other hand, are formed with the \isi{phrase} apïn=n ama- ‘eat with fire’, with the A argument referring to the person setting fire to something and the P argument referring to that which is burned (apïn ‘fire’ occurs in an \isi{oblique} \isi{phrase}) \REF{ex:syntax:297a}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï \textbf{apïn} im \textbf{ngamap}. | \gll nï \textbf{apïn=n} im nga=\textbf{ama}-p | \gls 1SG fire=OBL tree SG.PROX=eat-PFV | \glt `I burned this tree.’

Knowledge Point: Alternatively, apïn ‘fire’ can itself be the A argument (i.e., subject), with the P argument referring to that which is burned (i.e., ‘fire eats [something]’); since there is no \isi{animate} \isi{agent} here (the fire is the subject), this construction has, at least \isi{semantic}ally, something like an \isi{intransitive} meaning, although syntactically it is \isi{transitive} \REF{ex:syntax:297b}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Apïn} mï amun im \textbf{ndame}. | \gll \textbf{apïn} mï amun im ndï=\textbf{ama}-e | \gls fire 3SG.SUBJ now tree 3PL=eat-IPFV | \glt `The trees are burning now.’

Knowledge Point: There is an important \isi{bound morpheme} in Ulwa that serves a number of grammatical functions, often with nuances that are difficult to explain, but whose basic function seems to be to reduce the \isi{transitivity} of verbs \citep{Barlow2019b}. This is the verbal \isi{prefix} na- ‘\textsc{detr’} (i.e., “\isi{detransitivizer}”). Reasons for treating the detransitivizing form na- \textsc{‘detr’} as a \isi{prefix} rather than a \isi{clitic} include the fact that it only occurs before verbs and the fact that \isi{object-marker} \isi{proclitic}s may precede it. It may be seen in sentence \REF{ex:syntax:297c}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ndï \textbf{naytap}. | \gll ndï \textbf{na}-ita-p | \gls 3PL DETR-build-PFV | \glt `They built [something].’

Knowledge Point: In Ulwa, there are not strong distributional or structural differences between what may be thought of as \isi{transitive} and \isi{intransitive} verbs. Many verbs with meanings that are often considered prototypically \isi{intransitive} can, in Ulwa, have \isi{direct object}s and, as such, may be marked with \isi{object-marker} \isi{proclitic}s. For example, the verb ma- {\textasciitilde} i- ‘go’ can function simply as an \isi{intransitive} verb, requiring no object \REF{ex:syntax:298}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï \textbf{i}. | \gll nï \textbf{i} | \gls 1SG go.PFV | \glt `I went.’

Knowledge Point: As an \isi{intransitive} verb, ma- {\textasciitilde} i- ‘go’ may accept a \isi{postpositional phrase} to demarcate a \isi{goal} argument \REF{ex:syntax:299}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï \textbf{ndiya i}. | \gll nï ndï=\textbf{iya} \textbf{i} | \gls 1SG 3PL=toward go.PFV | \glt `I went to them.’

Knowledge Point: Alternatively, ma- {\textasciitilde} i- ‘go’ can function as a \isi{transitive} verb, with the \isi{goal} argument as its object. As an object, the \isi{goal} argument can, accordingly, receive \isi{object marking} \REF{ex:syntax:300}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï Kumba \textbf{may}. | \gll nï Kumba \textbf{ma=i} | \gls 1SG Bun 3SG.OBJ=go.PFV | \glt `I went to Bun [village].’

Knowledge Point: As a \isi{transitive} verb, ma- {\textasciitilde} i- ‘go’ may take an object even without an \isi{object-marker} \isi{proclitic} \REF{ex:syntax:301}.
Content 1: \gsrc Mï i wandam \textbf{iye}. | \gll mï i wandam \textbf{i}-e | \gls 3SG.SUBJ go.PFV jungle go.PFV-DEP | \glt `She went, went to the jungle.’

Knowledge Point: Furthermore, as a \isi{transitive} verb, ma- {\textasciitilde} i- ‘go’ can even have both a \isi{direct object} and a \isi{postpositional phrase} marking an additional destination (i.e., \isi{goal}), as in \REF{ex:syntax:302}. Thus the verb ma- {\textasciitilde} i- ‘go’ may be considered \isi{transitive} (or at least capable of being \isi{transitive}), taking as its \isi{direct object} a \isi{goal} argument. Even when there is no expressed object, the claim can be made that the verb is still \isi{transitive}, only that the \isi{direct object} has been left unexpressed.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï \textbf{maya} wa \textbf{may}. | \gll nï ma=\textbf{iya} wa \textbf{ma=i} | \gls 1SG 3SG.OBJ=toward village 3SG.OBJ=go.PFV | \glt `I went to him in the village.’

Knowledge Point: Although it is possible for the verb ma- {\textasciitilde} i- ‘go’ to function as an \isi{intransitive} verb without any special marking, it very commonly receives the detransitivizing \isi{prefix} na- \textsc{‘detr’}, which seems to serve the primary purpose of reducing \isi{transitivity}, in this case changing the verb’s meaning from something perhaps better glossed as ‘go to’ to something meaning simply ‘go’, as in \REF{ex:syntax:303} and \REF{ex:syntax:304}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ndï \textbf{nay}. | \gll ndï \textbf{na}-i | \gls 3PL DETR-go.PFV | \glt `They went.’
Content 2: \gsrc Mangusuwata \textbf{namana}. | \gll ma-ngusuwata \textbf{na}-ma-na | \gls 3SG.OBJ-poor DETR-go-IRR | \glt `The poor thing will be going.’

Knowledge Point: This same \isi{prefix} is seen on the verb ‘go’ also when a single argument is expressed in a \isi{postpositional phrase} (i.e., the \isi{goal} is not expressed as the \isi{direct object} of the verb), as in \REF{ex:syntax:305}.
Content 1: \gsrc Mï maya \textbf{nay}. | \gll mï ma=iya \textbf{na}-i | \gls 3SG.SUBJ 3SG.OBJ=toward DETR-go.PFV | \glt `He went to her.’

Knowledge Point: The same \isi{prefix} na- ‘\textsc{detr’} can occur with other verbs, also marking them as \isi{intransitive}. In example \REF{ex:syntax:306}, the verb ama- {\textasciitilde} la- ‘eat’ is \isi{transitive} (i.e., it has an overt object). This sentence may be compared with examples \REF{ex:syntax:307} and \REF{ex:syntax:308}, in which the same verb is \isi{intransitive}, in these examples being marked with the \isi{prefix} na- \textsc{‘detr’}.
Content 1: \gsrc Tïn mï \textbf{utam} \textbf{mamap}. | \gll tïn mï \textbf{utam} \textbf{ma=}ama-p | \gls dog 3SG.SUBJ yam 3SG.OBJ=eat-PFV | \glt `The dog ate the yam.’
Content 2: \gsrc Nï ta \textbf{namap}. | \gll nï ta \textbf{na}-ama-p | \gls 1SG already DETR-eat-PFV | \glt `I’ve already eaten.’
Content 3: \gsrc Ndul \textbf{nalanda}! | \gll ndï=ul \textbf{na}-la-nda | \gls 3PL=with DETR-eat-IRR | \glt `[Let’s] eat with them!’

Knowledge Point: The morpheme na- \textsc{‘detr’} is often better described as reducing the \isi{transitivity} of a verb rather than changing its \isi{valency}. In example \REF{ex:syntax:309}, the object of the verb is technically the \isi{question word} angos ‘what?’. However, given the fact that the event that the verb is encoding is far from being prototypically \isi{transitive} (i.e., the situation is non-punctual, \isi{irrealis}, etc.), it is not surprising that the detransitivizing \isi{prefix} na- \textsc{‘detr’} is employed.
Content 1: \gsrc Una angos \textbf{nalanda}? | \gll unan angos \textbf{na}-la-nda | \gls 1PL.INCL what DETR-eat-IRR | \glt `What shall we eat?’

Knowledge Point: Examples \REF{ex:syntax:310} and \REF{ex:syntax:311} illustrate how the verb ita- ‘build’ can likewise be detransitivized with the \isi{prefix} na- \textsc{‘detr’}. In example \REF{ex:syntax:310}, the verb is \isi{transitive} and receives the \isi{object marker} ma= ‘3\textsc{sg.obj}’; in example \REF{ex:syntax:311}, the verb is \isi{intransitive}, and receives the detransitivizing \isi{prefix} na- \textsc{‘detr’}.
Content 1: \gsrc Mï \textbf{wat maytap}. | \gll mï \textbf{wat} \textbf{ma}=ita-p | \gls 3SG.SUBJ ladder 3SG.OBJ=build-PFV | \glt `He built the ladder.’
Content 2: \gsrc Mï \textbf{naytap}. | \gll mï \textbf{na}-ita-p | \gls 3SG.SUBJ DETR-build-PFV | \glt `He built [something].’
Content 3: \gsrc Mï \textbf{wat maytap}. | \gll mï \textbf{wat} \textbf{ma}=ita-p | \gls 3SG.SUBJ ladder 3SG.OBJ=build-PFV | \glt `He built the ladder.’

Knowledge Point: Verbs glossed as ‘put’ in Ulwa, which take as their \isi{direct object} a \isi{goal} argument, are also commonly marked with the \isi{prefix} na- \textsc{‘detr’}, either when there is no specific \isi{goal} or when the speaker does not wish to include a \isi{goal} argument, as in examples \REF{ex:syntax:312}, \REF{ex:syntax:313}, and \REF{ex:syntax:314}.
Content 1: \gsrc I ndïn \textbf{nop}. | \gll i ndï=n \textbf{na}-u-p | \gls go.PFV 3PL=OBL DETR-put-PFV | \glt `[They] went and planted them [somewhere].’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Nay} mat \textbf{nalp} mat wapa nduwatlïpe. | \gll \textbf{na}-i ma=tï \textbf{na}-lï-p ma=tï wap ndï=wat-lï-p-e | \gls DETR-go.PFV 3SG.OBJ=take DETR-put-PFV 3SG.OBJ=take leaf 3PL=atop-put-PFV-DEP | \glt `[They] came, took him, put him [somewhere], put him on the leaves.’
Content 3: \gsrc Ndï namlipe mï ndït anmbï \textbf{nalpe}. | \gll ndï namli=p-e mï ndï=tï an-mbï \textbf{na}-lï-p-e | \gls 3PL soft=COP-DEP 3SG.SUBJ 3PL=take out-here DETR-put-PFV-DEP | \glt `When they were soft, she took them out.’

Knowledge Point: This \isi{prefix} may also be used when these ‘put’ verbs are used as the second element of verbal compounds, also with the effect of downplaying the \isi{direct object} (\isi{goal} argument) of the ‘put’ verb, as in \REF{ex:syntax:315} and \REF{ex:syntax:316}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ndï \textbf{mamune} \textbf{nop}. | \gll ndï ma=mune \textbf{na}-u-p | \gls 3PL 3SG.OBJ=throw DETR-put-PFV | \glt `They threw it around.’
Content 2: \gsrc Ndï nji ngalan \textbf{ndïnambï nop}. | \gll ndï nji ngala=n ndï=nambï \textbf{na}-u-p | \gls 3PL thing PL.PROX=OBL 3PL=skin DETR-put-PFV | \glt `They blocked them with these things.’

Subsection: The prefix na- ‘\textsc{detr’ as middle voice marker\label{sec:13.8.3
Knowledge Point: One function of the \isi{prefix} na- \textsc{‘detr’} seems to be to create something like a \isi{middle voice} construction, indicating that the \isi{agent} of the verb is also affected by the verb, without being its grammatical object. Thus the verb kuk- ‘gather’ can have a \isi{middle voice} sense when marked with the \isi{prefix} na- \textsc{‘detr’}, something like ‘assemble, unite, gather oneself’, as in \REF{ex:syntax:317}.
Content 1: \gsrc Mape \textbf{nakukawe}. | \gll ma=p-e \textbf{na}-kuk-aw-e | \gls 3SG.OBJ=be{-dep} DETR-gather-put.IPFV-DEP | \glt `While [he] was there, [they] were gathering.’

Subsection: The prefix na- ‘\textsc{detr’ with the verbs ni- ‘act’ and ni- ‘die’\label{sec:13.8.4
Knowledge Point: Sometimes the role of the \isi{prefix} na- \textsc{‘detr’} is not entirely clear. It occurs at times, for example, with the verb ni- ‘act, do’. It is not, however, always present; and it is difficult to explain its presence as a form of \isi{detransitivization}, as the verb ni- ‘act’ is not particularly \isi{transitive}. When it does select an argument (i.e., when the verb has the sense of ‘do [something]’), this argument is marked with the \isi{oblique marker} =n \textsc{‘obl’}, as in \REF{ex:syntax:318}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ndï makape wombïn \textbf{man} \textbf{ne}. | \gll ndï maka=p-e wombïn ma=\textbf{n} \textbf{ni}-e | \gls 3PL thus=COP-DEP work 3SG.OBJ=OBL act-IPFV | \glt `They used to do work like this.’

Subsection: The prefix na- ‘\textsc{detr’ with the verbs ni- ‘act’ and ni- ‘die’\label{sec:13.8.4
Knowledge Point: It could be argued that example \REF{ex:syntax:318} is actually \isi{transitive}, with the \isi{object marker} ma= \textsc{‘3sg.obj’} attaching directly to the \isi{verb stem}. Indeed, the surface form is [wo.mbïn.ma.ne], which does not offer any \isi{phonological} evidence of the \isi{oblique marker} /=n/, which -- I argue -- has \isi{deleted} before the immediately following /n/. However, its existence as an underlying form is supported by examples in which the \isi{allomorph} /=nï/ appears as the \isi{oblique marker} \REF{ex:syntax:319}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ndï makape wombïn \textbf{man} \textbf{ne}. | \gll ndï maka=p-e wombïn ma=\textbf{n} \textbf{ni}-e | \gls 3PL thus=COP-DEP work 3SG.OBJ=OBL act-IPFV | \glt `They used to do work like this.’
Content 2: \gsrc Wombïn \textbf{anmanï ne}. | \gll wombïn anma=\textbf{nï} \textbf{ni}-e | \gls work good=OBL act-IPFV | \glt `[They] were doing good work.’

Subsection: The prefix na- ‘\textsc{detr’ with the verbs ni- ‘act’ and ni- ‘die’\label{sec:13.8.4
Knowledge Point: Nevertheless, it is possible that the verb ni- ‘act, do’ is evolving to become more prototypically \isi{transitive}, helped in part by the \isi{phonological} ambiguity of forms such as those in \REF{ex:syntax:318}. This can perhaps explain what otherwise seems like redundancy in marking ni- ‘act’ with the detransitivizing \isi{prefix} na- \textsc{‘detr’}, seemingly without any change of meaning, as in \REF{ex:syntax:350}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ndï makape wombïn \textbf{man} \textbf{ne}. | \gll ndï maka=p-e wombïn ma=\textbf{n} \textbf{ni}-e | \gls 3PL thus=COP-DEP work 3SG.OBJ=OBL act-IPFV | \glt `They used to do work like this.’
Content 2: \gsrc Yena mï numan \textbf{mol nipe} mï asimu inap. | \gll yena mï numan ma=\textbf{ul} \textbf{ni}-p-e mï asi-mu ina-p | \gls woman 3SG.SUBJ husband 3SG.OBJ=with act-PFV-DEP 3SG.SUBJ grass-seed get-PFV | \glt `The woman made [her] husband buy rice.’

Subsection: The prefix na- ‘\textsc{detr’ with the verbs ni- ‘act’ and ni- ‘die’\label{sec:13.8.4
Knowledge Point: Similarly, the verb ni- ‘die’, which I take to be \isi{homophonous} rather than \isi{polysemous} with ni- ‘act, do’, nevertheless exhibits similar patterning, often occurring either with or without the \isi{prefix} na- \textsc{‘detr’}. Example \REF{ex:syntax:321} illustrates the presence of the \isi{prefix} na- \textsc{‘detr’} with the verb ni- ‘die’, whereas example \REF{ex:syntax:322} illustrates its absence.
Content 1: \gsrc Mï \textbf{nanip}. | \gll mï \textbf{na-ni}-p | \gls 3SG.SUBJ DETR-die-PFV | \glt `She died.’
Content 2: \gsrc Mï \textbf{nip}. | \gll mï \textbf{ni}-p | \gls 3SG.SUBJ die-PFV | \glt `She died.’

Subsection: The prefix na- ‘\textsc{detr’ with locative verbs\label{sec:13.8.5
Knowledge Point: The detransitivizing morpheme na- \textsc{‘detr’} is often used with the \isi{locative verb} p- {\textasciitilde} wap ‘be, be at (be located at)’ (\sectref{sec:10.1}, \sectref{sec:10.4}), commonly in conjunction with the form mbï ‘here’. It may serve the function of making the identification of the \isi{location} less definite, as in \REF{ex:syntax:323}. However, this is not always clearly the case. In \REF{ex:syntax:324}, it is not clear to me why the \isi{location} would be marked as less definite.
Content 1: \gsrc Una ango luwa lunda? Mbï \textbf{nawap}. | \gll unan ango luwa lo-nda mbï \textbf{na}-wap | \gls 1PL.INCL which place go-IRR here DETR-be.PST | \glt `Where should we have gone? We stayed.’
Content 2: \gsrc Wolka mo nay anmbï mbi mbï \textbf{nap}. | \gll wolka ma=u na-i an-mbï mbï-i mbï \textbf{na}-p | \gls again 3SG.OBJ=from DETR-go.PFV out-here here-go.PFV here DETR-be | \glt `Again, [we] came from there, came out here, and are staying here.’

Knowledge Point: Sometimes when the morpheme na- \textsc{‘detr’} affixes to the \isi{locative verb} p- ‘be at’, the verb seems to have a meaning closer to that of the generic \isi{copula} =p ‘\textsc{cop}’, which likely derived from it (\sectref{sec:10.3}). When used along with /p/, the \isi{prefix} na- \textsc{‘detr’} often gives the sense of ‘become’ rather than ‘be’, although this is not always the case. Although \isi{semantic}ally more similar to the \isi{copula}, the form [p] here is functionally more similar to the verb in that it allows a verbal \isi{prefix} (na- ‘\textsc{detr’}). This sort of ambiguity that exists between the \isi{locative verb} p- ‘be’ and the \isi{copular enclitic} =p ‘\textsc{cop}’ may be due to undergoing a process of \isi{grammaticalization}. Sentences \REF{ex:syntax:325} through \REF{ex:syntax:328} all convey the sense of ‘becoming’.
Content 1: \gsrc Mï wandam \textbf{nap}. | \gll mï wandam \textbf{na-p} | \gls 3SG.SUBJ jungle DETR-be | \glt `It’s become a jungle.’
Content 2: Not found

Subsection: The prefix na- ‘\textsc{detr’ with object-marker proclitics\label{sec:13.8.7
Knowledge Point: Rather more challenging to explain, the detransitivizing \isi{prefix} na- ‘\textsc{detr}’ may be used in conjunction with \isi{object-marking} \isi{proclitic}s. When present, the \isi{object marker} always precedes the \isi{prefix} na- ‘\textsc{detr}’. Interestingly, when the 3\textsc{sg} marker is used, it takes the subject form [mï=] and not the object form \textsuperscript{†}[ma=]. In other words, although functioning to indicate the object of the verb, the marker in such constructions has the formal appearance of a \isi{subject marker}. The fact that the morpheme na- ‘\textsc{detr}’ immediately precedes \isi{verb stem}s and follows \isi{object-marker} \isi{proclitic}s is support for the claim that it is a verbal \isi{prefix}. Sentences \REF{ex:syntax:329} through \REF{ex:syntax:332} exemplify the use of \isi{object marker}s along with the detransitivizing \isi{prefix} na- `\textsc{detr}’.
Content 1: \gsrc Mï mol anmbi inim naye \textbf{mïnape}. | \gll mï ma=ul an-mbï-i inim na-i-e \textbf{mï=na}-p-e | \gls 3SG.SUBJ 3SG.OBJ=with out-here-go.PFV water DETR-go.PFV-DEP 3SG.SUBJ=DETR-be{-ipfv} | \glt `It went with it out into the water and stayed around there.’
Content 2: \gsrc Min \textbf{ndïnasap}. | \gll min \textbf{ndï=na}-asa-p | \gls 3DU 3PL=DETR-hit-PFV | \glt `The two killed them.’

Subsection: The prefix na- ‘\textsc{detr’ with object-marker proclitics\label{sec:13.8.7
Knowledge Point: It may be that these forms have some level of reduced \isi{transitivity} or that the object of the \isi{transitive} verb is less definite. Sometimes, however, the \isi{direct object} of the verb marked with both the \isi{prefix} na- ‘\textsc{detr}’ and an \isi{object marker} is expressed as a full NP, as in examples \REF{ex:syntax:333}, \REF{ex:syntax:334}, and \REF{ex:syntax:335}. It is difficult to see the morpheme na- ‘\textsc{detr}’ as a means of reducing either \isi{transitivity} or \isi{definiteness} in examples such as these. That said, example \REF{ex:syntax:335} does seem best translated with an \isi{indefinite} article.
Content 1: \gsrc Ande an \textbf{wa mïnapïna}. | \gll ande an \textbf{wa} \textbf{mï=na}-p-na | \gls ok 1PL.EXCL village 3SG.SUBJ=DETR-be-IRR | \glt `OK, we’ll stay in the village.’
Content 2: \gsrc Yokombla mï nay \textbf{numbu mïnanip}. | \gll Yokombla mï na-i \textbf{numbu} \textbf{mï=na}-ni-p | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ DETR-go.PFV garamut 3SG.SUBJ=DETR-beat-PFV | \glt `Yokombla went and beat the garamut drum.’
Content 3: \gsrc \textbf{Apa ambi mïnaytana}. | \gll \textbf{apa} \textbf{ambi} \textbf{mï=na}-ita-na | \gls house big 3SG.SUBJ=DETR-build-IRR | \glt `[I] will build a big house.’
Content 4: \gsrc \textbf{Apa ambi mïnaytana}. | \gll \textbf{apa} \textbf{ambi} \textbf{mï=na}-ita-na | \gls house big 3SG.SUBJ=DETR-build-IRR | \glt `[I] will build a big house.’

Subsection: The prefix na- ‘\textsc{detr’ with object-marker proclitics\label{sec:13.8.7
Knowledge Point: In some instances, it seems that the simultaneous use of the detransitivizing \isi{prefix} na- ‘\textsc{detr}’ and an \isi{object marker} may be attributable to frequent use of the \isi{prefix} na- ‘\textsc{detr}’ with certain verbs. For example, verb forms such as [nay] (< na- ‘\textsc{detr’} + i ‘go.\textsc{pfv’}) are so common, that it could be that, for some speakers, the \isi{prefix} na- ‘\textsc{detr}’ has \isi{fossilized} to the verb root, having lost its original detransitivizing meaning, as for example in \REF{ex:syntax:336}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nay i nay Imwa \textbf{mïnay}. | \gll na-i i na-i Imwa \textbf{mï=na}-i | \gls DETR-go.PFV go.PFV DETR-go.PFV [place] 3SG.SUBJ=DETR-go.PFV | \glt `[They] went and went, went to Imwa.’

Subsection: The prefix na- ‘\textsc{detr’ with object-marker proclitics\label{sec:13.8.7
Knowledge Point: The hypothesis that [nay] has \isi{fossilized} as a monomorphemic form may be supported by the fact that it itself may receive the \isi{prefix} na- \textsc{‘detr’}, in effect giving the \isi{verb stem} two detransitivizing \isi{prefix}es, as in \REF{ex:syntax:337}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï mol nay wa mbï \textbf{nanay}. | \gll nï ma=ul na-i wa mbï \textbf{na-na}-i | \gls 1SG 3SG.OBJ=with DETR-go.PFV village here DETR-DETR-go.PFV | \glt `I went with her and came home here.’

Subsection: The prefix na- ‘\textsc{detr’ with object-marker proclitics\label{sec:13.8.7
Knowledge Point: The \isi{stem} kamb- ‘shun’ also frequently seems to have a \isi{fossilized} \isi{prefix} na- \textsc{‘detr’}, especially when the verb has the sense ‘suffice, have enough’, as in \REF{ex:syntax:338}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nambi \textbf{nakamp}. | \gll nï-ambi \textbf{na}-kamb-p | \gls 1SG-TOP DETR-shun-PFV | \glt `As for me, I’ve had enough.’

Subsection: The prefix na- ‘\textsc{detr’ with object-marker proclitics\label{sec:13.8.7
Knowledge Point: This form nakamb- ‘shun [\textsc{detr]}’ can also take an additional \isi{object marker}, as in examples \REF{ex:syntax:339} and \REF{ex:syntax:340}.
Content 1: \gsrc I ndï una \textbf{ndïnakam}. | \gll i ndï unan \textbf{ndï=na}-kamb | \gls way 3PL 1PL.INCL 3PL=DETR-shun | \glt `The [traditional] customs – we shun them.’
Content 2: \gsrc Una \textbf{ndïnakam} nay. | \gll unan \textbf{ndï=na-}kamb na-i | \gls 1PL.INCL 3PL=DETR-shun DETR-go.PFV | \glt `We left them and came.’

Subsection: Multiple na- ‘\textsc{detr’ prefixes on a single verb\label{sec:13.8.8
Knowledge Point: At times, however, the sheer number of na- \textsc{‘detr’} \isi{prefix}es in a given verb can be hard to account for \isi{morphosyntactic}ally -- even diachronically -- and may be most simply explained as a sort of filler, as in examples \REF{ex:syntax:341}, \REF{ex:syntax:342}, and \REF{ex:syntax:343}.
Content 1: \gsrc Unan \textbf{ndïnanalanda}. | \gll unan \textbf{ndï=na-na}-la-nda | \gls 1PL.INCL 3PL=DETR-DETR-eat-IRR | \glt `We will eat them.’
Content 2: \gsrc Mbï \textbf{nanap}. | \gll mbï \textbf{na-na}-p | \gls here DETR-DETR-be | \glt `[We] stayed around.’
Content 3: \gsrc Na ambi ndï mï \textbf{ndïnanatïn}. | \gll na ambi ndï mï \textbf{ndï=na-na}-tï-n | \gls talk big 3PL 3SG.SUBJ 3PL=DETR-DETR-take-PFV | \glt `The big stories – he got them [already].’

Knowledge Point: In this section I examine a phenomenon in Ulwa that may be analyzed as a change in \isi{valency} or as the \isi{demotion} of a verbal argument. It is possible for the \isi{semantic} object of a verb to appear as part of an \isi{oblique} \isi{phrase}. This occurs when an element intervenes between the (otherwise immediately preverbal) \isi{direct object} and the verb. The element that motivates this \isi{demotion} may be a \isi{postpositional phrase} or an \isi{adjective} functioning \isi{adverb}ially. In examples \REF{ex:syntax:344} through \REF{ex:syntax:347}, the logical object of the verb contains \isi{oblique} marking.
Content 1: \gsrc Ndï \textbf{ndïn} we ndul landa. | \gll ndï \textbf{ndï=n} we ndï=ul la-nda | \gls 3PL 3PL=OBL sago 3PL=with eat-IRR | \glt `[They] would eat them [= pieces of meat] with sago.’
Content 2: \gsrc Ndï wa \textbf{sokoyn} akïnaka ine. | \gll ndï wa \textbf{sokoy=n} akïnaka ina-e | \gls 3PL just tobacco=OBL new get-IPFV | \glt `They just harvest the tobacco prematurely.’

Knowledge Point: In example \REF{ex:syntax:348}, it seems that even the \isi{question word} anjikaka ‘how?’ can intervene, thereby motivating the \isi{demotion} of the object.
Content 1: \gsrc U \textbf{man} anjikaka tï inde iye mï ko liyu? | \gll u \textbf{ma=n} anjikaka tï inda-e i-e mï ko li-u | \gls 2SG 3SG.OBJ=OBL how take walk{-dep} go.PFV-DEP 3SG.SUBJ just down-put | \glt `How were you carrying it around such that it just fell?’

Knowledge Point: Events in which one participant causes another to act are expressed in Ulwa by a minimum of two clauses: one relating the \isi{causer} to the \isi{causee}, the other detailing the action of the \isi{causee}. In examples \REF{ex:syntax:349} and \REF{ex:syntax:350}, the verb ni- ‘act, do’ is used along with a \isi{postpositional phrase} \isi{head}ed by ul ‘with’ to convey the sense ‘force’. In these constructions, the clause with the \isi{causer} as subject is marked as \isi{dependent} with the \isi{dependent marker} -e ‘\textsc{dep}’ following the verb. This first clause may thus be translated with a causal sense (i.e., ‘since …’) (\sectref{sec:12.2.2}).
Content 1: \gsrc Itom mï Kongos \textbf{mol} \textbf{nipe} mï apa itap. | \gll itom mï Kongos ma=\textbf{ul} \textbf{ni}-p-e mï apa ita-p | \gls father 3SG.SUBJ [name] 3SG.OBJ=with act-PFV-DEP 3SG.SUBJ house build-PFV | \glt `Father made Kongos build a house.’
Content 2: \gsrc Yena mï numan \textbf{mol nipe} mï asimu inap. | \gll yena mï numan ma=\textbf{ul} \textbf{ni}-p-e mï asi-mu ina-p | \gls woman 3SG.SUBJ husband 3SG.OBJ=with act-PFV-DEP 3SG.SUBJ grass-seed get-PFV | \glt `The woman made [her] husband buy rice.’

Knowledge Point: In example \REF{ex:syntax:351}, a \isi{conditional} statement is used to convey the \isi{irrealis} sense of a \isi{causative}.
Content 1: \gsrc Itom mï Kongos \textbf{mol nipta} mï apa itana. | \gll itom mï Kongos ma=\textbf{ul} \textbf{ni}-p-ta mï apa ita-na | \gls father 3SG.SUBJ [name] 3SG.OBJ=with act-PFV-COND 3SG.SUBJ house build-IRR | \glt `Father will make Kongos build a house.’

Knowledge Point: The \isi{idiom} ‘act with’ (i.e., ‘force’) may be used in a single clause, without any other clause divulging what the person is forced to do, as in \REF{ex:syntax:352}. This lends further support to the claim that the \isi{causative} constructions in \REF{ex:syntax:349}, \REF{ex:syntax:340}, and \REF{ex:syntax:351} are all truly composed of two clauses each.
Content 1: \gsrc Itom mï Kongos \textbf{mol nip}. | \gll itom mï Kongos ma=\textbf{ul} \textbf{ni}-p | \gls father 3SG.SUBJ [name] 3SG.OBJ=with act-PFV | \glt `Father forced Kongos.’
Content 2: \gsrc Itom mï Kongos \textbf{mol} \textbf{nipe} mï apa itap. | \gll itom mï Kongos ma=\textbf{ul} \textbf{ni}-p-e mï apa ita-p | \gls father 3SG.SUBJ [name] 3SG.OBJ=with act-PFV-DEP 3SG.SUBJ house build-PFV | \glt `Father made Kongos build a house.’
Content 3: \gsrc Una \textbf{ndïnakam} nay. | \gll unan \textbf{ndï=na-}kamb na-i | \gls 1PL.INCL 3PL=DETR-shun DETR-go.PFV | \glt `We left them and came.’
Content 4: \gsrc Itom mï Kongos \textbf{mol nipta} mï apa itana. | \gll itom mï Kongos ma=\textbf{ul} \textbf{ni}-p-ta mï apa ita-na | \gls father 3SG.SUBJ [name] 3SG.OBJ=with act-PFV-COND 3SG.SUBJ house build-IRR | \glt `Father will make Kongos build a house.’

Knowledge Point: In addition to ‘act with’, there is another \isi{idiom} used in Ulwa to express compulsion. The form is nambïnïkï- ‘make, nag’ (literally ‘dig at [one’s] skin’). It conveys a weaker level of pressure than ul … ni- ‘make, force’, and may be seen in \REF{ex:syntax:353}.
Content 1: \gsrc Yena mï numan \textbf{manambïnkape} mï asimu inap. | \gll yena mï numan ma=\textbf{nambï-nïkï-}p-e mï asi-mu ina-p | \gls woman 3SG.SUBJ husband 3SG.OBJ=skin-dig-PFV-DEP 3SG.SUBJ grass-seed get-PFV | \glt `The woman made her husband buy rice.’

Knowledge Point: The fact that examples such as \REF{ex:syntax:350} and \REF{ex:syntax:351} are sets of two clauses is suggested by uses of these \isi{causative} \isi{verb phrase}s in situations where the would-be \isi{causee} fails to complete the action, as in \REF{ex:syntax:354} and \REF{ex:syntax:355}.
Content 1: \gsrc Yena mï numan \textbf{mol nipe} mï asimu inap. | \gll yena mï numan ma=\textbf{ul} \textbf{ni}-p-e mï asi-mu ina-p | \gls woman 3SG.SUBJ husband 3SG.OBJ=with act-PFV-DEP 3SG.SUBJ grass-seed get-PFV | \glt `The woman made [her] husband buy rice.’
Content 2: \gsrc Itom mï Kongos \textbf{mol nipta} mï apa itana. | \gll itom mï Kongos ma=\textbf{ul} \textbf{ni}-p-ta mï apa ita-na | \gls father 3SG.SUBJ [name] 3SG.OBJ=with act-PFV-COND 3SG.SUBJ house build-IRR | \glt `Father will make Kongos build a house.’
Content 3: \gsrc Yena mï numan \textbf{mol nipe} mï ango asimu inap. | \gll yena mï numan ma=\textbf{ul} \textbf{ni}-p-e mï ango asi-mu ina-p | \gls woman 3SG.SUBJ husband 3SG.OBJ=with act-PFV-DEP 3SG.SUBJ NEG grass-seed get-PFV | \glt `Even though the woman pressured [her] husband, he didn’t buy rice.’
Content 4: \gsrc Yena mï numan \textbf{manambïnkape} mï ango asimu inap. | \gll yena mï numan ma=\textbf{nambï-nïkï-}p-e mï ango asi-mu ina-p | \gls woman 3SG.SUBJ husband 3SG.OBJ=skin-dig-PFV-DEP 3SG.SUBJ NEG grass-seed get-PFV | \glt `Even though the woman nagged [her] husband, he didn’t buy rice.’

Knowledge Point: Commands or \isi{request}s made in \isi{reported speech} may be viewed as forms of causatives, provided that the \isi{command} or \isi{request} being made leads to an action being performed. An example is given in \REF{ex:syntax:358}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Nan mate} mï i masamasa mowonp. | \gll \textbf{na=n} ma=\textbf{ta}-e mï i masamasa ma=won-p | \gls talk=OBL 3SG.OBJ=say-DEP 3SG.SUBJ go.PFV tree.species 3SG.OBJ=cut-PFV | \glt `[She] told him to go cut the tree.’

Knowledge Point: In Ulwa, \isi{command}s expressed in \isi{reported speech} reveal a distinction between \isi{realis} and \isi{irrealis} \isi{mood}s. In \ili{English}, for example, there is a degree of ambiguity created by sentences that employ \isi{non-finite verb form}s (i.e., \isi{infinitive}s), such as the following: Mary told John \textbf{to leave}. Namely, it is not clear whether John actually left or not. In Ulwa, however, the \isi{TAM} of the verb (e.g., leave in the \linebreak \ili{English} example) reveals whether the \isi{imperative} led to the desired outcome (\isi{realis}) or not (\isi{irrealis}). This may be seen with a contrasting pair of sentences, one with \isi{perfective} \isi{aspect} (i.e., \isi{realis} \isi{mood}) \REF{ex:syntax:356} and another with \isi{irrealis} \isi{mood} \REF{ex:syntax:357}.
Content 1: \gsrc Mawna mï \textbf{nan} Yawat \textbf{mate} mï \textbf{i}. | \gll Mawna mï \textbf{na=n} Yawat ma=\textbf{ta}-e mï \textbf{i} | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ talk=OBL [name] 3SG.OBJ=say-DEP 3SG.SUBJ go.PFV | \glt `Mawna told Yawat to leave [and he did].’
Content 2: \gsrc Mawna mï \textbf{nan} Yawat \textbf{mate} mï \textbf{mana}. | \gll Mawna mï \textbf{na=n} Yawat ma=\textbf{ta}-e mï ma-\textbf{na} | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ talk=OBL [name] 3SG.OBJ=say-DEP 3SG.SUBJ go-IRR | \glt `Mawna told Yawat to leave [but it is unclear whether or not he did].’

Knowledge Point: Sentence \REF{ex:syntax:359} provides another example of a \isi{causative} in \isi{indirect discourse}, this one illustrating \isi{irrealis} \isi{mood}.
Content 1: \gsrc Unan \textbf{na} \textbf{makïta} mï \textbf{ndambikulilïnda}! | \gll unan \textbf{na} ma=\textbf{kï}-ta mï ndï-ambi=kuli-lï-\textbf{nda} | \gls 1PL.INCL talk 3SG.OBJ=say{-cond} 3SG.SUBJ 3PL-TOP=throw-put-IRR | \glt `Let’s tell him to throw them away!’

Knowledge Point: When someone or something is caused to have a certain attribute, Ulwa uses an \isi{idiom} with the verb me{}- ‘sew’. The object of this verb is the acquired attribute, and that which acquires it is expressed as an \isi{oblique} \isi{phrase} designated by the \isi{oblique marker} =n ‘\textsc{obl}’ (literally ‘sew [the attribute] to [that which acquires it]’). Examples of such \isi{factitive} (or \isi{translative}) constructions are given in \REF{ex:syntax:360}, \REF{ex:syntax:361}, and \REF{ex:syntax:362}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Ndïn} wapata \textbf{mep}. | \gll ndï=\textbf{n} wapata \textbf{me}-p | \gls 3PL=OBL dry sew-PFV | \glt `[He] made them [= sores] dry.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Amblan} mundotoma \textbf{menda}. | \gll ambla=\textbf{n} mundotoma \textbf{me}-nda | \gls PL.REFL=OBL short sew-IRR | \glt `[We] will make ourselves short.’
Content 3: \gsrc Kïka mï awlu apa mo \textbf{man} tembi \textbf{mep}. | \gll kïka mï awlu apa ma=u ma=\textbf{n} tembi \textbf{me}-p | \gls white.ant 3SG.SUBJ step house 3SG.OBJ=from 3SG.OBJ=OBL bad sew-PFV | \glt `The white ant nest has come to the house and made it bad.’

Knowledge Point: In examples \REF{ex:syntax:360}, \REF{ex:syntax:361}, and \REF{ex:syntax:362}, the \isi{adjective}s either may be functioning as \isi{abstract noun}s or may (as is common in \isi{translative} constructions in other languages) be functioning as \isi{predicate adjective}s. Example \REF{ex:syntax:363} contains the noun kalam ‘knowledge’, which also commonly functions either as an \isi{abstract noun} (‘knowledge’) or as an \isi{adjective} (‘knowledgeable, knowing’) (\sectref{sec:5.4}).
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Ndïn} wapata \textbf{mep}. | \gll ndï=\textbf{n} wapata \textbf{me}-p | \gls 3PL=OBL dry sew-PFV | \glt `[He] made them [= sores] dry.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Amblan} mundotoma \textbf{menda}. | \gll ambla=\textbf{n} mundotoma \textbf{me}-nda | \gls PL.REFL=OBL short sew-IRR | \glt `[We] will make ourselves short.’
Content 3: \gsrc Kïka mï awlu apa mo \textbf{man} tembi \textbf{mep}. | \gll kïka mï awlu apa ma=u ma=\textbf{n} tembi \textbf{me}-p | \gls white.ant 3SG.SUBJ step house 3SG.OBJ=from 3SG.OBJ=OBL bad sew-PFV | \glt `The white ant nest has come to the house and made it bad.’
Content 4: \gsrc Nan ndïtap \textbf{ndïn} kalam \textbf{mendat}. | \gll na=n ndï=ta-p ndï=\textbf{n} kalam \textbf{me}-nda-t | \gls talk=OBL 3PL=say-PFV 3PL=OBL knowledge sew-IRR-SPEC | \glt `[We] told them so that [we] might teach them.’

Knowledge Point: The ‘teaching’ construction in \REF{ex:syntax:363} encodes in its \isi{oblique} \isi{phrase} the \isi{recipient} of the knowledge. It is also possible for such constructions to admit two \isi{oblique} phrases, one denoting the \isi{recipient} of the knowledge and the other denoting the material being taught (literally ‘sew knowledge to someone with [respect to] something’), as is illustrated by example \REF{ex:syntax:364}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nan ndïtap \textbf{ndïn} kalam \textbf{mendat}. | \gll na=n ndï=ta-p ndï=\textbf{n} kalam \textbf{me}-nda-t | \gls talk=OBL 3PL=say-PFV 3PL=OBL knowledge sew-IRR-SPEC | \glt `[We] told them so that [we] might teach them.’
Content 2: \gsrc Nï nji \textbf{ngalan} \textbf{unï} kalam \textbf{men}. | \gll nï nji ngala=\textbf{n} un=\textbf{nï} kalam \textbf{me}-n[da] | \gls 1SG thing PL.PROX=OBL 2PL=OBL knowledge sew-IRR | \glt `I will teach you these things.’

Knowledge Point: In example \REF{ex:syntax:365}, the object of the verb is a title that has been acquired.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Amblan} ini tamndï \textbf{mep}. | \gll ambla=\textbf{n} ini tamndï \textbf{me}-p | \gls PL.REFL=OBL ground owner sew-PFV | \glt `[They] made themselves the owners of the land.’

Knowledge Point: While the verb me{}- ‘sew’ is the most common verb used in these constructions, the same \isi{factitive} concept can be expressed with other verbs that show that a new quality is being ‘attached’, as in examples \REF{ex:syntax:366} and \REF{ex:syntax:367}, which use the \isi{compound verb} watlï- ‘put atop’.
Content 1: \gsrc Simban yeta tï \textbf{ambïwatlïpe}. | \gll Simban yeta tï ambï=\textbf{wat-lï}-p-e | \gls [name] man take SG.REFL=atop-put-PFV-DEP | \glt `Simban made herself [like] a man.’
Content 2: \gsrc Mï yeta ambi tï \textbf{ambïwatlïp}. | \gll mï yeta ambi tï ambï=\textbf{wat-lï}-p | \gls 3SG.SUBJ man big take SG.REFL=atop-put-PFV | \glt `He’s [like] a grown man!’

Knowledge Point: Constructions expressing permission function similarly to \is{biclausal construction} biclausal \isi{causative} constructions (\sectref{sec:13.9.1}). In the first clause is the verb ka- ‘let, leave, allow’, which takes as its object the person or thing being granted permission; in the second clause, the subject is this person or thing being granted permission, and the verb explains what this subject is being permitted to do, as in \REF{ex:syntax:374}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Ndïlakan} ndï mapïn! | \gll ndï=la-\textbf{ka}-n ndï ma=p-na | \gls 3PL=IRR-let-IMP 3PL 3SG.OBJ=be-IRR | \glt `Let them stay there!’

Knowledge Point: First, it may be shown how the verb ka- ‘let, leave, allow’ functions in simple \isi{monoclausal construction}s. It should be noted that, in these clauses, the object of the verb is the \isi{location} in which someone or something is being left. That which is being left, on the other hand, may be expressed in an \isi{oblique} \isi{phrase} using the \isi{oblique marker} =n ‘\textsc{obl}’.\footnote{Compare the argument structure of the verb lï- ‘put’ (\sectref{sec:9.2.2}). For the irregular \isi{circumfix}-like \isi{irrealis} form of the verb ka- ‘let, leave, allow’, see \sectref{sec:4.3} and \sectref{sec:9.2.3}.} Sentences \REF{ex:syntax:368} through \REF{ex:syntax:372} illustrate the use of ka- ‘let, leave, allow’ in simple \isi{monoclausal construction}s.
Content 1: \gsrc Mol i man Simundo \textbf{maka}. | \gll ma=ul i ma=n Simundo ma=\textbf{ka} | \gls 3SG.OBJ=with go.PFV 3SG.OBJ=OBL [place] 3SG.OBJ=let | \glt `[They] went with him and left him at Simundo [village].’
Content 2: \gsrc Wana \textbf{malakana}! | \gll wana ma=la-\textbf{ka}-na | \gls PROH 3SG.OBJ=IRR-let-IRR | \glt `Don’t abandon it!’

Knowledge Point: Notably, when functioning in \is{biclausal construction} biclausal \isi{permissive} constructions, the verb ka- ‘let, leave, allow’ takes as its object the thing being permitted, as in \REF{ex:syntax:373}, as opposed to a \isi{location}, as in \isi{monoclausal sentence}s such as \REF{ex:syntax:368} and \REF{ex:syntax:369}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Ndïnji ndïlaka} ndï mïnap. | \gll \textbf{ndï-nji} \textbf{ndï}=la-ka ndï mï=na-p | \gls 3PL-POSS 3PL=IRR-let 3PL 3SG.SUBJ=DETR-be | \glt `[They] let their possessions [just] stay [as they are].’
Content 2: \gsrc Mol i man Simundo \textbf{maka}. | \gll ma=ul i ma=n Simundo ma=\textbf{ka} | \gls 3SG.OBJ=with go.PFV 3SG.OBJ=OBL [place] 3SG.OBJ=let | \glt `[They] went with him and left him at Simundo [village].’
Content 3: \gsrc Dingo man \textbf{maka}. | \gll Dingo ma=n ma=\textbf{ka} | \gls [name] 3SG.OBJ=OBL 3SG.OBJ=let | \glt `[They] left Dingo there.’

Knowledge Point: Such constructions often make use of \isi{conditional} clauses, especially in \isi{command}s \REF{ex:syntax:375}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Unanji malakata} mï ina! | \gll \textbf{unan-nji} \textbf{ma=la-ka-ta} mï i-na | \gls 1PL.INCL-POSS 3SG.OBJ=IRR-let-COND 3SG.SUBJ come-IRR | \glt `Let our [granddaughter] come!’

Knowledge Point: These \isi{permissive} \isi{conditional sentence}s may be contrasted with sentence \REF{ex:syntax:376}, in which the \isi{conditional} verb form lakata ‘let, leave, allow [\textsc{cond}]’ is used in a \isi{protasis} to mean, simply, ‘leave’ (i.e., it is not a \isi{permissive} construction); here, the object of lakata ‘let [\textsc{cond]}’ is the \isi{location} where something is left.
Content 1: \gsrc Ndïn mumnopen luwa \textbf{lakata} tomoy ndïwat mana. | \gll ndï=n mumne-u-p-en luwa la-\textbf{ka}-ta tomoy ndï=wat ma-na | \gls 3PL=OBL cold.and.dark-put-PFV-NMLZ place IRR-let-COND insect.species 3PL=atop go-IRR | \glt `If [they] were to leave them in a cold and dark place, [then] insects would go onto them.’

Knowledge Point: Finally, it may be noted that the verb ka- ‘let, leave, allow’ is used frequently in an \isi{idiom} meaning something like ‘forget about it!’, ‘don’t’ even mention it!’, or ‘amazing!’. In such expressions, the \isi{object marker} typically takes the \is{topic-marker pronoun} topic-marked pronominal form (\sectref{sec:6.6}) and the verb takes an \isi{irrealis} or \isi{imperative} form. This use of ka- ‘let’ is illustrated by examples \REF{ex:syntax:377} and \REF{ex:syntax:378}.
Content 1: \gsrc A \textbf{mambilakan}! | \gll a ma-ambi=la-\textbf{ka}-n | \gls ah 3SG.OBJ-TOP=IRR-let-IMP | \glt `Ah, forget it!’
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: The expression of wants follows patterns very similar to those of \isi{indirect discourse} (\sectref{sec:13.4.5}). Indeed, the most common way of expressing that one wants something to happen is to use a verb of speaking or thinking, typically kï- ‘say’ and typically expressed in the \isi{perfective} \isi{mood} and with the detransitivizing \isi{prefix} na- \textsc{‘detr’} (thus: [nakap], literally ‘said’ or ‘thought’). This form has likely been somewhat \isi{fossilized} as a word used to express desires. The clause expressing the desire is a \isi{dependent clause} embedded within a \isi{matrix clause} that has as its subject the person who desires something. The verb in the \isi{dependent clause} is always marked as \isi{irrealis}, as in sentences \REF{ex:syntax:379} through \REF{ex:syntax:382}. Brackets enclose the \isi{embedded clause}s.
Content 1: \gsrc Sokoy ulwape nï nïnji wa mana \textbf{nakap}. | \gll sokoy ulwa=p-e nï [nï-nji wa ma-na] \textbf{na-kï-p} | \gls tobacco nothing=COP-DEP 1SG [1SG-POSS village go-IRR] DETR-say-PFV | \glt `Since there’s no tobacco, I want to go to my village.’
Content 2: \gsrc Na ndan nïkïna \textbf{nakap}? | \gll {[na} anda=n {nï-kï-na]} \textbf{na-kï-p} | \gls {[talk} SG.DIST=OBL 1SG=say-IRR] DETR-say-PFV | \glt `Do [you] want to tell me something?’

Knowledge Point: The subject of the \isi{matrix clause} (the person desiring something) need not be the subject of the \isi{embedded clause} (the \isi{agent} desired to do something). In sentence \REF{ex:syntax:383}, the subject of the \isi{matrix clause} is an understood third party, whereas the subject of the \isi{embedded clause} is the speaker (1\textsc{sg)}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï mana \textbf{nakap} nï mïnjan mat: … | \gll {[nï} {ma-na]} \textbf{na-kï-p} nï mïnja=n ma=ta | \gls {[1SG} go-IRR] DETR-say-PFV 1SG speech=OBL 3SG.OBJ=say | \glt `[Wala] wanted me to go, but I told him: …’

Knowledge Point: The form [nakap], as seen in \REF{ex:syntax:383}, can be used regardless of \isi{TAM} distinctions: thus, for example, many sentences with this form have \isi{imperfective} force, despite the typically perfective-marking \isi{suffix} -p \textsc{‘pfv’}. Moreover, the form [nakap] may be used without any \isi{conditional} marking, even in the \isi{protasis} of a \isi{conditional sentence}, as in \REF{ex:syntax:384}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï mana \textbf{nakap} nï mïnjan mat: … | \gll {[nï} {ma-na]} \textbf{na-kï-p} nï mïnja=n ma=ta | \gls {[1SG} go-IRR] DETR-say-PFV 1SG speech=OBL 3SG.OBJ=say | \glt `[Wala] wanted me to go, but I told him: …’
Content 2: \gsrc Nan nïkïna \textbf{nakap} na kali nïwatlïta. | \gll {[na=n} {nï=kï-na]} \textbf{na-kï-p} na kali nï=wat-lï-ta | \gls {[talk=OBL} 1SG=say-IRR] DETR-say-PFV talk send 1SG=atop-put-COND | \glt `If [you] wanted to talk to me, [then you] should have sent a message to me.’

Knowledge Point: In example \REF{ex:syntax:385}, the \isi{conditional} marker -ta \textsc{‘cond’} occurs within the \isi{embedded clause}, instead of being affixed to the \isi{matrix clause} verb form [nakap] (cf. issues of \isi{scope} in \sectref{sec:13.3.4}).
Content 1: \gsrc Wutï munta lunda \textbf{nakap} … | \gll {[wutï} mune-ta {lu-nda]} \textbf{na-kï-p} | \gls {[leg} throw-COND put-IRR] DETR-say-PFV | \glt `If you want to throw your legs around …’

Knowledge Point: The \isi{semantic} connection between verbs of speaking or thinking and verbs of desiring is understandable. Often, when one wants something, one talks about it (and almost certainly thinks about it). While [nakap] seems to be a \isi{fossilized} form used in \isi{desiderative} clauses, it is nevertheless possible to use other verbs of speaking to express desires, as in the \isi{desiderative} sentence given in \REF{ex:syntax:386}, which uses the verb ta- ‘say’.
Content 1: \gsrc Nul mana \textbf{nate}. | \gll {[nï=ul} {ma-na]} \textbf{na-ta-e} | \gls {[1SG=with} go-IRR] DETR-say-DEP | \glt `[He] wanted to go with me.’

Knowledge Point: In addition to these \is{biclausal construction} biclausal \isi{desiderative} constructions, it is possible to express a desire in a single clause, simply by using an \isi{irrealis} verb form. In such instances, it is not necessarily clear whether the person desiring the event encoded by the verb is the subject of the verb, the speaker of the clause, or both. In examples \REF{ex:syntax:387} through \REF{ex:syntax:391}, all translated with ‘want’, the \isi{irrealis} verb forms could, in other contexts, impart other meanings (e.g., ‘will’, ‘should’, ‘can’, etc.; see \sectref{sec:4.6}).
Content 1: \gsrc Nï lamndu \textbf{mawalinda}. | \gll nï lamndu ma=wali-\textbf{nda} | \gls 1SG pig 3SG.OBJ=hit-IRR | \glt `I want to kill a pig.’
Content 2: \gsrc Nï ango wa \textbf{lunda}. | \gll nï ango wa lo-\textbf{nda} | \gls 1SG NEG village go-IRR | \glt `I don’t want to go around in villages.’

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{ex:syntax:391} illustrates a \isi{negative desire}. Often, to express that something is not desired, the verb kamb- ‘shun’ (\sectref{sec:2.1.2}) is used. It may take either the \isi{imperfective} (or unmarked) form kam ‘shun [\textsc{ipfv}]’, the \isi{imperfective} form kambe ‘shun [\textsc{ipfv]’}, or the \isi{perfective} form kamp ‘shun [\textsc{pfv]’}, as shown in \REF{ex:syntax:392}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï ango wa \textbf{lunda}. | \gll nï ango wa lo-\textbf{nda} | \gls 1SG NEG village go-IRR | \glt `I don’t want to go around in villages.’
Content 2: \gsrc Nï \textbf{kam(be/p)}! | \gll nï \textbf{kamb(-e/-p)} | \gls 1SG shun(-IPFV/-PFV) | \glt (a) ‘I don’t want to!’

Knowledge Point: To express that an object is desired, Ulwa simply employs the verb tï- ‘take’ in the \isi{irrealis} \isi{mood}. After all, to say, for example, that one ‘wants a spear’ means that one ‘wants to take (i.e., obtain, have) a spear’. In other words, a proclamation such as ‘I would take’ links, by inference, to ‘I want’. This is illustrated in \REF{ex:syntax:393} and \REF{ex:syntax:394}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï mana \textbf{tïna}. | \gll nï mana \textbf{tï-na} | \gls 1SG spear take-IRR | \glt `I want a spear.’
Content 2: \gsrc Nï awal mana akïnaka \textbf{tïna}. | \gll nï awal mana akïnaka \textbf{tï-na} | \gls 1SG yesterday spear new take-IRR | \glt `I wanted a new spear yesterday.’

Knowledge Point: Often the distinction between ‘want’ and ‘need’ in such instances is not explicit. Sentence \REF{ex:syntax:395} thus may be translated variably.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï mana akïnaka \textbf{tïna}. | \gll nï mana akïnaka \textbf{tï-na} | \gls 1SG spear new take-IRR | \glt (a) ‘I want a new spear.’
